That was hell of a humbling experience.

The only reason I played this was because I was fully convinced it wouldn't make me emotional. I ended up sobbing non-stop for 3h straight (*insert skull emoji*)
Shit, my entire body is still aching from crying, I can barely see my keyboard due to tears. 

10/10,  [b]never[/b] again

author: {'steamid': '76561198247323432', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1675580834}
review:
Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a poignant and emotionally gripping visual novel duology that delves into the complexities of life, love, and the human spirit. This thought-provoking narrative is a must-play for those who appreciate deep, character-driven stories with a touch of melancholy.

Narcissu 1st follows the story of a young woman named Yuu, who is diagnosed with a terminal illness and decides to spend her remaining days in a rural hospital. Here, she meets Tatsusio, a middle-aged man who has been living a life of solitude due to his health issues. Together, they form an unlikely bond, sharing their thoughts, fears, and dreams as they confront the harsh realities of their circumstances.

Narcissu 2nd serves as a prequel to the first chapter, offering a glimpse into the lives of the characters before their fates intertwined. This installment explores themes of loneliness, regret, and the search for meaning in life. The narrative is both heart-wrenching and beautifully crafted, leaving a lasting impact on the reader.

One of the most striking aspects of Narcissu is its minimalist visual style, which complements the somber tone of the story. The simple, yet effective art design allows the focus to remain on the characters and their emotional journeys. The soundtrack is equally evocative, with its haunting melodies enhancing the overall atmosphere.

The gameplay in Narcissu is straightforward, with the majority of the experience revolving around reading the narrative and making occasional choices that may slightly alter the course of the story. However, the core appeal of this duology lies in its deeply moving story and the relatable emotions it evokes.

In conclusion, Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a poignant and unforgettable experience that transcends the boundaries of the visual novel genre. It serves as a powerful reminder of the fragility of life and the importance of cherishing every moment. This thought-provoking duology is a must-play for anyone seeking a deeply emotional and introspective journey.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089209561', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1708032091}
review:
Narcissu is a game that is simultaneously easy and unbelievably hard to describe. It is about the passage of time, into a future they shall never know, and those who are stuck in time. A drivers license never to be used. A middle-school English textbook never finished. A girl, stuck as she was, all those years ago. The world is one stuck in time, the date may change and winter may start to pass, but for them its the same every day - the same programmes on the television, the same scene outside the window. And it's heartbreaking. Unbearably so. There is a point, around 3 quarters through the game, when the girl, Setsumi, comments that Donkey's live longer than wolves, perhaps, because they are useful. For them, they are not useful, and so they shall die, surrounded by fake smiles. What's worse is they have no choice in this. They shall be discharged three times, and after the third time they shall be discharged no more, and will be faced with the final choice, the only choice they have left - to die at home or on the seventh floor.

The question asked then, is how they will choose to live the life they have left. What do you do with the little time you have left in a world that has stopped for you? What can you do with the little time you have left? The outcome may be certain - it is one we knew from the very start - but the journey they embark on, both real and metaphorical, is not.

The music, haunting and beautiful, the art, restrained and poignant, builds this utter sense of hopelessness and despair. But do not believe that this is a game bereft, as are its characters, of all hope and happiness. For against the magnitude of their situation every minor happiness, every moment of joy and pleasure, no matter how small, such as the simple act of buying clothes, inspires an unbelievable sense of happiness.

And when this all comes together it creates a deep connection to its characters and its themes, and an experience that is hard not to recommend.

In short - play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199107888635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 1159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1159, 'last_played': 1706857445}
review:
[h1] 8.5/10 [/h1]

Within the realm of visual novels, the Narcissu series has always been a refreshing presence. Its unique themes, simple yet vivid character portrayal and emotional depth, moving music, and a profound and deep story core have elevated the series' influence well beyond the visual novel community. Now that we have the opportunity to experience the two most acclaimed works of the series for free, why not seize this chance to embark on an unforgettable journey that offers a new understanding of life and death?

Narcissu 1st's storyline is not lengthy, yet it tells a touching tale of the fleeting moment of ordinary individuals, characterized by their naive bravery and soul-stirring simplicity. It's a narrative that belongs solely to its characters, portraying their ephemeral lives with poignant beauty. Narcissu 2nd, serving as a prequel, utilizes flashbacks and a non-linear narrative to unravel the many clues hidden in the first game, providing a more rigorous logic to character actions and a more vivid and three-dimensional portrayal of its characters. What stands out the most in both works is the profound depiction of the psychological, social, and familial changes brought about by illness, presented with great sensitivity and realism. Combined with an exceptional literary quality and music that is both melancholically beautiful and romantic, primarily piano compositions, this visual novel of artistic and literary caliber promises to deliver an unforgettable experience.

It's undeniable that the experience provided by this work is somewhat lacking. Issues such as unreadable font sizes, outdated interface design, abrupt transitions, and the absence of character names in dialogues inevitably detract from the player's experience. The overall deep and heavy narrative atmosphere and the simplistic plot indirectly raise the barrier to entry. References to Greek mythology and popular Japanese fairy tales in key plot points do not easily resonate with players, and many reflections and metaphors on life, philosophy, and religion require careful contemplation for understanding. As one of the early examples of visual novels in the strictest sense, Narcissu 1st&2nd merely represent a simple digitization of novels. Players have no room for choices or interaction; they are merely observers of the story, resulting in limited gameplay.

Both works exude a serene melancholy and deep contemplation of life, with Narcissu 2nd, in particular, leaving many thought-provoking questions for the player through its detailed and subtle descriptions. These games are recommended for players who enjoy philosophical reflections and stories that are both profound and realistic. It is also advised to ensure you are in a calm and peaceful state of mind when playing to achieve the best experience. While many players believe the storyline of Narcissu 2nd does not compare to its predecessor, I firmly believe that Narcissu 2nd's portrayal of gentleness and strength, and how people remain pure at heart despite struggling and floundering against fate, is the most touching aspect. I hope you can also find your own unique insights and emotions in this work.

review:
Esta novela visual si no me acuerdo mal la tuve por aÃ±os en mi biblioteca de Steam y apenas hace poco decidÃ­ probarla. Y luego de jugarla he de decir que me ha gustado mucho la verdad. Aunque como toda cosa buena tiene sus cosas no tan buenas. 

Quiero decir que usted lee mi reseÃ±a/opiniÃ³n por favor tenga cuidado con los spoilers.

[list] [b]Cosas que me gustaron fueron:[/b]

    [*]Esta novela visual logra hacer sentir al jugador, [spoiler]la manera en la que poco a poco te hacen encariÃ±arte para cuando se llega al desenlace te duela es magnÃ­fico.[/spoiler]
    [*]El Side 2nd es MUY bueno, [spoiler]aquÃ­ le ves el sentido del porque de algunas cosas que ves en la parte principal de esta novela visual,[/spoiler] y la verdad soy fan de eso.
    [*]El poco arte que se ve de los personajes es genial, no solo porque es muy bonito, sino porque [spoiler] como se ve pocas veces, le da un mejor impacto a las situaciones a mi parecer.[/spoiler]
    [*]La mÃºsica de este juego es muy buena, es muy buena como sonido ambiental (Lo siento, no me se una mejor frase/palabra) 
    [*]El epÃ­logo fue algo que ame que estuviera, [spoiler] ya que a mi me encanta ver lo que pasa luego de las historias de los juegos, y esta novela visual te muestra al prota luego de su aventura.[/spoiler]
    [*]Las voces en esta novela se sienten como un buen acompaÃ±ante, te ayudan a entender mejor con que sentimiento dicen las cosas los personas y le da mas fuerza a los diÃ¡logos.
[/list]

[list] [b]Cosas que no me gustaron fueron:[/b]

    [*]El formato/manera en la que se lee la novela es algo incÃ³modo a mi parecer, en mi caso esto hizo que la vista se me cansara mucho al inicio, pero cuando me acostumbrÃ© no estuvo tan mal, pero es algo incomodo la verdad.
    [*]Como esta novela esta Ãºnicamente en inglÃ©s, y no conozco al 100% este idioma, se me hizo complicado el entender algunas cosas, como [spoiler]si la chica a la que el prota le da el legado del piso 7 es la hermana de Himeko o una nueva persona, esta duda mÃ­a surge por la imagen del final mas que nada.[/spoiler]
[/list]

Por si la persona que estÃ© leyendo esto le interesa hay una [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=373869489] traducciÃ³n [/url] que alguien hizo para esta novela, lo malo es que esta solo se aplica para la primera parte de la novela (la descubrÃ­ luego de haberla leÃ­do completa, jaja).

Esta historia me gusto tanto que me interesa el jugar las otras entregas de esta historia cuando tenga el dinero para comprarlas. 

Espero haberme entendido bien y haberme explicado medianamente bien, no soy tan bueno para expresarme y elegir las palabras correctas, le deseo a la persona que estÃ© leyendo esto un buen dÃ­a/tarde/noche.

EDIT: Arreglos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198312332607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1700977559}
review:
Narrative based game in which you are to listen and read through the story of "disease and suffering".

it is mainly a perspective and perception game where the player should get some sort of an idea of how the characters feel at the given moments. it is a minimal interaction game and does not any learning of any mechanics or controls to complete this narrative based game.

An easy to 100% game which adds to your "perfect game" statistics. Enjoy!

review:
The end just blow up my mind.
It is so good parallel with the story about Narcissus.
I mean what did she want in the end?
Did she want to be stopped and hear those words? 
It meaningless in that circumstances. 
And she said she gave up.
But still I waited for them.
I just hoped they could spent a bit more time together.
And know each other a bit better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157975638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 842, 'last_played': 1699355940}
review:
Going through this game felt like I was frequently taking concentrated doses of despair, pain, guilt, and anger. It is depressingly bleak, but there is beauty in characters and their actions. It gave me a new perspective on some aspects of life and made me appreciate some of the things I have taken for granted. And the soundtrack is hauntingly beautiful.

Gameplay-wise, it has some design choices that might affect the experience of some, but it didn't affect my enjoyment the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198445233952', 'num_games_owned': 60, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1707367319}
review:
... And so, our journey of 960km ended... 
To me, it was 15 days time. 
To her, it was the end of 22 year journey. 
Not the 7th floor, nor home. Of her own will, she avoided them. 
In the year 2005, she was one of the estimated 35,000 people who committed suicide. 
Blood type, O, name, Setsumi, 22 years old, female... 
Vinyl identification bracelet, white. 
This was everything about the girl.
... But, I knew. 
In reality, she liked bikini swimsuits, knew more about the roads than a navigation system, 
and loved cars. She even had a license.
She was always without expression, and would only rarely face you, 
but once in a while, 
she would even make this embarrassed, pouting face... 
The emerald sea to her back... 
As if dancing, happily, like a magazine model, she smiled... 
And yet... 
On this cheap disposable camera, only a single picture remained of her smile.
...But even so...
...Even with just one picture... 
It was the proof of ourselves that we left behind...

author: {'steamid': '76561198025253428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1694988596}
review:
Anemoia: the feeling of nostalgia that never was

The avidity of such strong empathy to a life that wasn't mine and a journey that never will be

Experiencing the narrative like a deep, vivid dream-like substance within her whispering voice, ever slowly overpowering all other senses...

This is truly what it feels to be alive!

To live for but a single purpose, to face an ever impeding deepest void beyond

Towards Narcissus, towards Daffodils, towards the Emerald sea, endlessly numb.

author: {'steamid': '76561198834560758', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1687865722}
review:
this story is genuinely one of the most heart-wrenching stories ive experienced. the second story kinda dragged on for me personally BUT it 100 percent made up for it having so many links to the first part and gave more character in general to the characters. i definitely recommend this one, maybe make sure youre not super emotional on either end of the scale, because it will make you sad.

its genuinely worth the 5 hours that it took me to read it all, and you really should experience it for yourself.

review: This visual novel took me on an unforgettable emotional ride. With graphics that may not blow you away, the captivating story compensates tenfold. Prepare for tear-jerking moments and profound existential reflections. The dialogue is beautifully written, making you forget you're playing a game. Amidst the somber theme, there's a surprising touch of humor that brings balance. It's a thought-provoking masterpiece that proves games can be more than just entertainment. Buckle up and get ready for a journey that'll leave you questioning life itself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122624865', 'num_games_owned': 281, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1685518773}
review:
What a dreadfully nihilistic, sentimental, and poignant experience Narcissu was. 
Does Narcissu have a great narrative? Not really. Does it even have great dialogue? No. Are the cgs or characters great? Nope.

What Narcissu does offer, however, is a highly realistic portrayal of two clinically-ill patients who are very rapidly succumbing to their illness; both psychically and mentally. And, in their newly founded philosophical abyss, impulsively decide to futilely fight against their environment and fate. Following that, we see both the characters on a road trip where, metaphysically, they create their own life and undergo introspection and self-discovery together. Some important questions get raised: is it the destination or the journey that matters? When faced with the prospect of death within weeks; do you surrender or precede in meaningless defiance? Is there any inherent purpose or meaning to our fleeting lives? Yadda yadda. 

Now, Narcissu does have good writing and a decent plot. But, what it does not have is good pacing, transitions, or story length. 
The pacing in this novel is far too fast--about as fleeting as Seimitsu's life. And, on top of that, the transitions and abrupt chapter endings are not only jarring, but take you out of the atmosphere. Now, the story length itself leaves very little room for your feelings to mature, and, as for the the two main characters, it's a similar story. Not only are the characters particuarly uninteresting; the dialogue itself tends to be very boring oftentimes. But, when it does hit--it hits. And, in the same vein, probably a bit more realistic all things considered.  As for the ending, it's prdictable but impactful. Yet, gets completely eroded by the sudden, jarring credits scene that info dumps/rehashes the story and the main character while cheerful music plays in the background. That, singlehandedly, almost ruined the entire experience for me. 
Aside from that, the minimalist soundtrack and CGs work greatly with the game's hallow, bittersweet, and unnerving atmosphere. 

Is it worth the 5 hours of playtime, I'd say so. And, in my opinion, Narcissu is better than the majority of short VNs, such as Planetarian. 

6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198046602411', 'num_games_owned': 388, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1685580598}
review:
As with many "deep" VN stories I've read, the "deep" personalities of each character seem to boil down to just saying "I don't know" and "does it matter" and "I am too afraid to make decisions or choices in life". I find this extremely annoying about japanese culture in general. I don't find indecisiveness to be realistic. Most people don't have any trouble making decisions, since weighing positives and negatives of a choice is a very straightforward and basic thought process. I feel like Japanese culture values this lack of straightforwardness in conversation as some sort of thing to be praised due to some preconception of politeness. But to me it seems like people never actually talk, they just try to tell each other as little as possible and avoid real communication out of fear of seeming too blunt. Surely this will lead to good relationships. I can see why the characters in this game would be suicidal when no one actually talks to them, instead saying "betsuni" 24/7. A good "f*** off" would fix that I think. But not really in VN vernacular to be so honest. Anyway I'll talk about the actual game.

This game doesn't have enough visuals. A lot of the time on screen there is just a grey square and text. I could count like 2-3 pictures of the female character in the first part, and those show for about 1% of the dialogue. This is really bare bones. It would be better off being a book with a soundtrack you could play while reading it.

If I had to describe the writing in this VN, it would be "thoughtful and empathetic, but strangely childish". It sets out to point out that terminally ill people feel abandoned by society, as if this is some sort of revelation people did not know about. By considering such an illness for a little bit one could divine the mental state someone having one would end up in. So this game's story doesn't really reveal something that unique regarding its central topic. But it does tell it with a lot of care so it is enjoyable to read in a way.

The second part of the story is a bit more lighthearted for a large portion of it and overall longer. It's a bit refreshing in that way, but many of the chapters amount to nothing. Chapter 5: Setsumi and Himeko eat ice cream. Setsumi learns Himeko likes cars. (we already knew that though) Chapter 6: Setsumi and Himeko plant a bulb in the garden and eat croquettes. Setsumi sees flowers and Himeko tells her they are Narcissus WOW JUST LIKE THE ONES IN THE FIRST PART OF THE GAME...is a whole chapter necessary for this? Chapter 7: They eat croquettes again. Himeko says the reason she thinks she has an illness is because she is being punished for not going to church enough as a catholic. (Yes this is all that matters to the story in the entire chapter.)

There's also a lot of "*stares at sky* ah, how lonesome it's beautiful and blue", "once again, the cicadas are singing", we don't need this every single day in the game. We understand by a sound effect or two if it's clear weather or raining etc.

Story: Solid, if overly marred by indecisive, distant communication between characters and pointless interactions
Visuals: Not good, barely any to speak of
Music: Great, probably the best aspect of the game

I don't recommend it because there are many many VNs with sad endings that you should consider before this one, which is very basic and probably not worth your time despite being free. Yuki Gotou is in it though, so maybe play just the second part to hear her if you like her voice acting. The "Opening video" for Narcissu 2nd (actually about 1 hour into the story though) has Riya as a vocalist too, which sounds really nice.

The 2nd game also tried to have some sort of deep comment on christianity (not to make it seem bad or good necessarily though) but it seems like the writer didn't understand the concept of afterlife. If you are going to die, you don't expect god to let you live suddenly by praying. You pray and follow the teachings of christianity to be saved in the afterlife. In the game the characters are getting fed up with their prayers because god doesn't magically cure their diseases. Not really how the concept of prayer works.

author: {'steamid': '76561198867333159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 610, 'last_played': 1700163411}
review:
I have read multiple VN's, seen multiple movies and series and read a lot of books. But this one stands out of the bunch. When it comes to how emotional masterpieces are created they take one of two forms. The first one is having the main focus about being a tearjerker and is there to make you cry. The other one is to teach the person reading/watching abotu something. This message can then dig so deep into your heart that you end up crying anyways. I have always found the latter one to be more impactful on my life but Narcissu stood out to me. 

Narcissu is a VN that does not have the main focus about being a tearjerker and neither does it have a specific message. The thing that makes this one special is that it does not teach you anything new but rather makes you think hard about something you already know which is about life and death. Already at a young age our bodies surpress these deep thoughts about life and death unconsciously. This is because its too deep of a topic and will bring a great deal of mental stress when thought about. This VN however forces you to think about those things which can have a drastic change on how you view your own life. That is why this VN is so powerful. 

Through this VN you will yourself be able to find your own view on life, the value of it, how you want to live your own life. Not to mention that this VN is entirely free and was made to be free. The whole purpose of this VN was for people to get a grasp on what life truly means in their own way. There is no right or wrong when it comes to this question, just how you yourself feel.

Even though the Artstyle is old and it does not seem to be of high quality at first glance every single one of these things are intentional so that you have the opportunity to dive deep into your inner thoughts. There will never be a VN quite like this one and there will never be a VN that can have this big of an impact on your life. I will say it once more. This VN is the best VN of all time when it comes to changing the person reading it. And it will probably remain that way for a very long time. 

If you ever feel like you need a change of view over your life do not hesitate to read this VN. It is totally worth it

final score 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198316203376', 'num_games_owned': 64, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1682746393}
review:
5 minutes to get all achievements.

100% Achievement Guide
â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“
â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“
Finished Narcissu 1st (voiced)
Very simple, all you need to do is press start, select the first title, any translation and make sure that you select voiced. Once you have done this just hold down the CTRL key, wait until you finish the prologue and continue throughout all the chapters. Pressing the SPACE key furiously will take approximately an hour longer.
Finished Narcissu 1st (unvoiced)

Repeat exactly what you did the first time except select unvoiced. Also, you don't have to go and press CTRL through the whole story again, you can just easily select the last chapter (Chapter 08).
Finished Narcissu 2nd (voiced)

Now that you have finished both achievements for Narcissu 1st it is time to move on to 2nd. Select the second title, choose whatever translation and make sure that you select voiced, just like the first time. Now power through it again with CTRL.
Finished Narcissu 2nd (unvoiced)

Keep everything the same, select unvoiced and got through Chapter 19.
Finished Narcissu 2nd Epilogue

For some reason this achievement is hidden, but it only requires you to go to Epilogue & full credits. Make sure you have gotten all the other achievements before trying to get this one. Voicing does not matter.

author: {'steamid': '76561199011800674', 'num_games_owned': 71, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1686144459}
review:
I've yet to play side second, so I'm writing this solely for 1st.

Even though I knew what'd happen at the end, it still managed to be great. But the characters, especially Setsumi, should've been a bit more fleshed out. She didn't seem as important to me as this story tried to make her. It's understandable, since this is a ~90 min VN, but for that reason, I really think this should be longer.
I'd recommend at least trying this one though, since in no means it was bad, and it's free.

8.5/10 for now, let's see if my opinion changes after side second.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089693705', 'num_games_owned': 759, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 1182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1182, 'last_played': 1669281664}
review:
Narcissu 1st and 2nd was a fairly good visual novel. It had an emotional and thought-provoking story, even if a few elements were predictable and standard fare for this sort of story. It was also not long enough to overstay its welcome, which it easily could have done, but it also wasn't short enough to feel too fleeting. Another bonus is that the game was fully voiced, so there was more emotion that could be gained from the game. 

Despite these praises, the game, unfortunately, has very limited graphics and music. For the majority of the game, you will just be looking at a flat background with some text with a few music tracks that constantly loop. This tends to make the experience of playing this game pretty boring, as the story itself isn't exactly the most invigorating, and the game itself doesn't have much substance.

Overall, this game was a pleasant and thought-provoking read that was full of emotion. However, it was a bit boring at times due to the lack of features in the game. Despite this, I would still recommend giving it a try, especially since it is free.

author: {'steamid': '76561199124646131', 'num_games_owned': 35, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1696324007}
review:
This visual novel is the oldest one I've ever played. And to my shock, it's also one of the best ones I've ever played! The story is magnificent. The two story paths, have an amazing interconnection, and play along unlike any other visual novel I have personally encountered. The voice acting is great too!

Probably the best use of my 9ish hours I spent on this game. 10/10!

(also macOS users : this game is falsely marked as 32 bit, it works on modern macOS versions!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198309018442', 'num_games_owned': 225, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1680179190}
review:
one summer, one meeting, one one parting

narcissu tells the story of the 7th floor of a hospital, where it is said that patients will not return to the room for the third time.

a short story that is presented very well in terms of the speed of the story and the way it is delivered, although the story is only set in 40 days but that time is enough to make me feel close to the characters and can shed tears for what happened to them.

from patients who rarely show their emotions to patients who are very positive despite having problems with their belief in God.

narcissu promises a story that touches the heart and brings a smile, whether in part 1 or part 2.

the minim visual presentation also gives freedom of imagination to the player to give their own interpretation.

As a game that is given for free, Narcissu really gives a very good surprise in terms of story and music.

author: {'steamid': '76561198876104672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1698762630}
review:
M A N

I knew from the tone of the story that there would be no miracles happening but i was happy with the ending. even though there might be no one to hear our prayers, even if life dealt us a bad hand. We are given ways to live our final days. To give one last act of defiance and to say our final goodbyes. I think narcissu will be a worthwhile experience for anyone when you're feeling melancholic or just want a VN with a bittersweet ending.

author: {'steamid': '76561198388143886', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1675869779}
review: a short story about finding peace in death. it's short, impactful and emotional, it deals with some very serious topics which are rarely the main focus in most projects like terminal illness and religion. the game raises a lot of questions about the morality of the protagonist's actions, suicide and life itself which really make you think about what you believed thus far. the soundtrack is phenomenal and the art, although scarce, is memorable whenever it's present. "with the birth of purpose, the fear of loss also was born."

author: {'steamid': '76561199013378608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 956, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1677036221}
review:
[h1]If there is a prayer, then there is also a curse...[/h1]

[b]This kinetic VN can be sum up in a short Latin phrase, I've learnt at school. "Memento mori".[/b]

Narcissu took me by surprise completely. I've had no idea what I picked up (it was free on Steam, so I thought I'll give it a try). It is probably the saddest story among visual novels, I have read. Basically, it all starts in a hospice care. So, you know...there's no such a thing as good, happy ending here...
I wasn't prepared for that, as it reminded me of my close friend, who passed away, suffering from cancer few years back. Narcissu brought all the memories. Honestly, it is well written story with believable main character. Himeko (I will always call her "å§«") acted, just like my friend...
It's a heartbreaking story in two parts. You will cry in both of them. Just don't forget to check epilogue, upon finishing Narcissu 2nd. It's short, but it will squeeze even more tears from you.
Tomo Kataoka made a truly unforgettable experience. Even with its predictable and sad ending, story forced me to think again about my own life and how precious it is. And if you have something to tell to your friend, family member or a lover - it's best not to wait until the last minute, because it might be too late at the end...

From technical point of view - it's nothing special, mind you - it's a novel from 2005, so resolution is low. However - it is voiced vn and soundtrack is amazing. Plus, it's completely FREE and it is one of the best titles in the genre.
Depend on your reading speed, story is around 7 hours long.

[b]Overall, if you want to read something that will get you emotional, I strongly recommend this title. Despite its technical flaws, I'm giving it 9/10 score. It's beautiful and unique. [u]The 7th Floor...damn...I don't know if I would be strong enough to be a helper there...

author: {'steamid': '76561199073942592', 'num_games_owned': 67, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1673412277}
review:
Narcissu 1st and 2nd is a Japanese visual novel game that was released in 2005 and 2007, respectively. The game is a story about a young man named Setsumi, who is hospitalized with terminal cancer, and a girl named Himeko, who is also a patient at the hospital. The game tells the story of their relationship and their experiences with illness, death, and the meaning of life.

The game's art and music are both excellent, with beautiful backgrounds and a moving soundtrack that effectively sets the tone of the story. The writing is also well-done, with a poignant and emotional narrative that explores themes of love, loss, and hope. The characters are well-developed, and the player becomes deeply invested in their stories.

One of the game's strengths is its ability to address serious and heavy themes in a way that is both sensitive and thought-provoking. It manages to be both poignant and uplifting, while avoiding being maudlin or sentimental. The game's ending is also particularly well-done, offering a satisfying conclusion to the story while also leaving room for interpretation.

Overall, Narcissu 1st and 2nd is a powerful and moving visual novel that tells a beautiful and emotionally resonant story. It is a must-play for fans of the visual novel genre and anyone who appreciates thought-provoking storytelling.

Please note the game contain sensitive theme such as terminal illness and death, If you might find it hard to deal with, you may want to consider before playing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000985742', 'num_games_owned': 400, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1673137577}
review:
Narcissu's story is beautiful and while sad, it's never manipulatively depressing I feel - as it exits with a heartwarming and uplifting message

Technically speaking there's some stuff to complain about like music/effects volume resetting every time you close it, and Setsumi's voice-acting very clearly having background noise during the first story, but that's nothing, especially from something that's free

author: {'steamid': '76561198072501662', 'num_games_owned': 131, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 843, 'last_played': 1707422506}
review:
A very solid read with a lot of care and attention put into the story.

In terms of the individual novels, Narcissu 1 is a proof of concept and Narcissu 2 is a prequel to it that is longer, introduces more characters, and establishes the setting in a more elaborate manner.

Both volumes feature the girl named Setsumi who, like some of the other characters from the hospital, experiences terminal illnesses. She connects the two volumes together in all stages of her illness, as you both get to experience the setting in her shoes as well as from the outside perspective of another character called Yuu.

The topic of exploration isn't so much about the nature of the disease itself, but more so about how it influences the characters, their development, relationships, perspective, among other things. The realisation that sooner or later these characters are going to die while bound to living the rest of it in the hospital or home, sets up an underlying melancholy mood. However, the story gets engaging and quite climactic as story progresses.

The character dynamic and the topics explored, as well as the overall presentation, are definitely the strong points of this visual novel.

On that note, I strongly recommend giving this one a read.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040559678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 460, 'last_played': 1662306230}
review:
this is a beautiful visual novel that i'd recommend to anyone who can handle the sad subject matter. as some other reviewers have mentioned, this is a railroad visual novel â€“ so don't expect to make any choices, instead you should just sit back and enjoy the ride. 

at first, i could only read bit by bit because i was struggling with my mental health at the time but the characters quickly gripped my heart and i had to push on regardless to find out how it would all end. though it might be a tragic story, it ended up being quite cathartic and gave me a lot to think about. 

i cried, i'm won't to lie, but there's no shame in crying and it's free, so if you think that you'd be interested even a little... you should try it! you can play it in any order you want, but i played 2nd before 1st and found that it gave me a lot more insight.

author: {'steamid': '76561198162040719', 'num_games_owned': 34, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1661676129}
review:
9/10

Positives:
> Really good BGM for scenes
> Simple but really nice "water color" style art
> Good story
> Great way to introduce yourself to visual novels

Negatives:
> Non-interactive visual novel (might be a turn off to people who may have played a few VNs)

Review
For me, this isn't my first experience in playing visual novels. However this is my first visual that has a pretty heavy theme for its story line. The story of the both parts of the game gives you the chance to think about your view of life and really puts you in the shoes of the characters. 

Lastly, don't expect different routes or story line for Narcissu. This game is a non-interactive visual novel means there are no routes. It's basically reading a book with voice acting and a nice BGM 

With that said, I recommend this game for people who are starting or just new with the visual novel genre of games. It gives you a peek for what to expect in visual novels, specially with genre staples for the VN category. 

P.S - They really should've put a trigger warning, this game might not be healthy for everybody. Deducted a point for that because the story might rub off some people the wrong way.

review:
No, I'm not crying. I just went out to touch grass and got dirt in my eyes.

In all seriousness, an amazing visual novel. Highly recommend. The story is deep and thought-provoking and really does make you look at the big picture.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have some screenshots I need to look at and cry about.

author: {'steamid': '76561199042657548', 'num_games_owned': 614, 'num_reviews': 281, 'playtime_forever': 905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 905, 'last_played': 1661098957}
review:
ğ™’ğ™šğ™¡ğ™˜ğ™¤ğ™¢ğ™š ğ™©ğ™¤ ğ™©ğ™ğ™š "ğ™¨ğ™©ğ™šğ™§ğ™ğ™¡ğ™š ğ™˜ğ™¡ğ™šğ™–ğ™£, ğ™¬ğ™ğ™ğ™©ğ™š ğ™¥ğ™¡ğ™–ğ™˜ğ™š ğ™¬ğ™ğ™šğ™§ğ™š ğ™©ğ™ğ™š ğ™˜ğ™šğ™ğ™¡ğ™ğ™£ğ™œ ğ™ğ™¨ ğ™ğ™ğ™œğ™ğ™šğ™§ ğ™©ğ™ğ™–ğ™£ ğ™ªğ™¨ğ™ªğ™–ğ™¡, ğ™–ğ™£ğ™™ ğ™©ğ™ğ™š ğ™¬ğ™ğ™£ğ™™ğ™¤ğ™¬ğ™¨ ğ™¤ğ™¥ğ™šğ™£ ğ™£ğ™¤ ğ™¢ğ™¤ğ™§ğ™š ğ™©ğ™ğ™–ğ™£ ğ™›ğ™ğ™›ğ™©ğ™šğ™šğ™£ ğ™˜ğ™šğ™£ğ™©ğ™ğ™¢ğ™šğ™©ğ™šğ™§ğ™¨"

ğ€ğ›ğ¨ğ®ğ­ ğ­ğ¡ğ ğ ğšğ¦ğ:

My mind has always been excited by the idea of the ability of any story to influence a person's thinking, his emotional state, or the ability to simply linger in his head. And to some extent it is crazy that the story is placed there by an absolutely stranger, but does not lose its closeness to you because of this.
But how does this happen? Why can absolutely anyone influence you with their own legend, what should the latter be? And everything is very simple and difficult at the same time: you need to be sincere and invest a part of yourself.
Stage-nana is the most ordinary and "everyday" developers who released an ordinary, at first glance, kinetic novel in 2007.
They operated with a soundtrack, a small amount of text and a very regressive picture at that time, but they, unlike many other developers, actually managed to give me an abyss of pleasant memories, a swarm of thoughts and a great many tender feelings. Hence my perception is clouded, and the hand draws only a positive picture of the world of this game.
But I'll try to be objective.

The plot in Narcissus tells about two sick people, a girl and a guy, who dutifully await their inevitable death, as a result of a disappointing diagnosis, on the white and sterile expanses of a special, 7th floor. But something is happening and the situation is changing dramatically.

The graphic component, as I wrote above, is at a really average level. However, this does not prevent the game from looking atmospheric and very original, especially against the background of modern novels. The same planetarium from the studio "Key" is made in a similar style and both works are iconic.

The most important part of the game is the soundtrack . Extremely subtle, dramatic and comprehensive, it literally permeates you with the most diverse emotions, making you worry, rejoice, laugh, as if you were the main character of the novel.

There is a lot of text in the game and it is written well, I did not notice any errors in the English version of the game.

ğ‘ğğ¬ğ®ğ¥ğ­:

Narcissu is a diamond among visual novels. With its budget, the difficulties of development in this segment and other difficulties at the time of the creation of the game, Stage-nana managed to immerse us in a wonderful story that can give you a whole life full of bitterness and joy in just one evening.

author: {'steamid': '76561199109881770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1679370425}
review:
Note: Have only finished Narcissu 2nd Side and completed it first

From the beginning to right before the Nello & Alois flashbacks began, I thought this game was simply good. It was fairly descriptive and varied in tone with a well made soundtrack but had a fair amount of issues with regards to story focus and character structure. I didn't like the lack of focus on Yuka and to a lesser extent Chihiro. I also found the pacing to be a bit too scattered and disconnected. 

However, after those flashbacks began and especially when they started to become dark, the game just absolutely blew apart my expectations and then blew them apart again. How everything just came together thematically and emotionally was just unbelievable. The thematic handling of loss of faith and the complicated feelings of grief and suicide could not have been handled better. I was completely speechless. And the music particularly "For Whose Sake" and "Route 1" complimented these strong emotions masterfully. The conclusion was just outstanding.

Ultimately, it wasn't even just how the game handled grief and existentialism and loss of faith but instead how it tackled faith itself and how it connects with the human condition. The affirming and beautiful (but absolutely not naive) presentation of religion and faith despite the terrible inevitable circumstances really gets to the heart of why faith matters so much to people and why it continues to endure. Just amazing to see such an astoundingly accurate portrayal of this by a Japanese writer.

review:
I've just finished the first game (Narcissu 1st)...
If you are new to visual novels, I beg you to give this game a chance, specially for its short and well-written story.
I'm honestly amazed at how much grief and distress this game made me feel towards the characters and the situation they are in.

review:
Well that was f*cking depressing. The story was more than a bit dramatic, but it can be good to try to see things from the perspective of someone who relies on others for basic life necessities.
For reference, I have a significant amount of firsthand experience with hospice care.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116857655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1657945354}
review:
As someone whose grandparents died in hospice and was at my father's side helping take care of him in home hospice, and dealing with health issues myself that have taken a lot from me (and leaving me to fight bitterness every day still) this game is one that I probably should have played long ago. It might have helped a few things, and it may have changed a few things. Be prepared that this game will get heavy.

There are people that will be too afraid to contemplate death for the young and the old to even play. Those are the same people that will leave someone over the same crap and leave them to attempt to come to grips with things on their own.

If you are one of the people who has a friend or relative in hospice, or know you are likely heading there yourself some day, then I encourage you to play this game.

review:
One of the best games you can play for free â€“ in fact I'd happily recommend Narcissu if it cost money too. 
This game creates such a great atmosphere by combining minimal aesthetics with haunting music and bittersweet storytelling. There aren't that many games around these days that understand the value of minimalism â€“ a lot of modern developers could learn a lot from this classic indie masterpiece.

author: {'steamid': '76561198416001479', 'num_games_owned': 70, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 968, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1662750972}
review:
A little girl who lost her place in life, an outcast in this place we call terra, but in the end she went away, so far away from this place to find her own happiness, a place where she belongs.

The BGM and the story, despite being somewhat short, deserves some praise. God this sounds good. Feels like I'm back in the 90s/early 2000s with the song compositions. I loved this visual novel. It gave me the same feels as Clannad did.

author: {'steamid': '76561199215715149', 'num_games_owned': 174, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1653229986}
review:
Honestly An Amazing Visual Novel... One Of The Better Ones I Have Had The Pleasure Of Reading... Amazing Story And Lore, Paired With Great Voice Acting... For A Relatively Old Visual Novel Its Very Good...

However, My Voiced And Subtitled Versions Was Stuck In Japanese... I Know Some But Not Alot So I Understood Most Of It...

Overall Would Recommend 10/10 Very Emotional And Moving... Also It's Free... What Do You Have To Loose?...

review:
I've tried several times to get into it, but it does not evoke my curiosity and interest. I feel most, even action, games I would have proceeded more plot than I have into this sole visual novel. Maybe that's how visual novels are, but not the ones I've been reading. So plot wise, its very slow.

Based on the other reviews, it might be worth it, but based on how much more unknown effort I need to put in, it also might not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198358098222', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1646040344}
review:
For me 7/10, it totally needed an auto button (cause I hate to spam click) and sometimes it gets messy to understand who's talking... Gladly, the voiced version helps us a bit more with that.
I liked the 1st one more than the 2nd one, because the later is a bit more heavy on the theme, and it just serves to justify somethings on the first one.
I see a lot of people complaining about the sensitive topic. I didn't felt like it was described in a "violent" way, it felt realistic, without much sugar-coating, without the "we'll safe you, and there's a way out" and I appreciated that. I think the people that feels more sensitive about this "theme" are probably more religious type of people, because this is a reality! And yes there are people that suffer and are draw to these things.
Japanese society doesn't see it in the same way as us, and it's not that the story doesn't give you some lights of hope, or at least alert to the self-loving topic.
It's a free game, and I do recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198866716523', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1644934920}
review:
Don't make mistake, this is a masterpiece without a shred of doubt but I don't recommend it to you at all.
This is not the type of content that should be easily accessed, as it is dark, way too dark for average human being.
As it has high chance of making you sad, making you experience negative emotions and shortening your lifespan and damaging your mental health, I insist that you stay away from this.
Heed my words, you will regret this.

P.S. I thought the first one was horrible enough to cause me nightmares and overeating but the second one shattered my heart completely.

Nothing is free in this world.
If there is a prayer, there is a curse. 
Everything in this world has equivalent price. 
If a prayer comes true, something else will be taken away from you.

Once again the access to this game should be restricted, this game is a curse and not the one people should bear for being curious.

author: {'steamid': '76561199217264024', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 515, 'last_played': 1652264727}
review:
How would the sea embrace you, in its countless watery arms?
Would the final moments of our agony be, warm and comforting, or cold and uncaring?
We know neither, but what truly matters is that the voiceless sea does not complain nor does it care.
For it is neither malevolent nor benevolent, it is just a silent resting place for tormenting souls.
So walk into it and let yourself be free...

author: {'steamid': '76561198829801737', 'num_games_owned': 99, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 693, 'last_played': 1644406406}
review:
A clean and minimal kinetic VN with a very touching story behind it.
Although it feels slow at times, it describes the experiences of disease and medicine, and how it affects the patients and their family in adverse and tragic ways.
[h2] A journey on the border of life and death and the helplessness that comes alongside it[/h2]

review: A nice, short, cute game that will first create a somber yet fun atmosphere lulling you into a false sense of security and then proceeding to rip out your tear ducts and squeeze them over your lifeless body as the end credits song plays and you lie there unable to process what the fuck is going on around you besides the unbelievable tragedy and heartbreak that you just experienced at the hands of this game. 10/10 the OST is great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124901879', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1641189339}
review:
It's really good, on the shorter side (less than 10 hours), and is completely free. Definitely worth a read; when it comes to free visual novels, it really doesn't get better than this.

I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of Narcissu; despite its age (2005-2007) and lack of a price tag, the visual novel holds up incredibly well. The story is well-written and is as touching as it is tragic. The backdrops are beautifully drawn, though the art style for the characters are likely hit or miss. The evocative soundtrack delivers, adding to the immersion (esp. eufonius imo, best known for the song "Holograph" used in Yumiko's route in the Grisaia series). Give it a shot. You won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198341641231', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 547, 'last_played': 1625480271}
review:
One of (if not) the best free visual novels out there.
It depends on reading speed, but it doesn't take long to finish. Short reading time compared to other VNs.
It's an old work, so the soundtrack feels pretty dated. However, the music is still good and gets you immersed into the story.
Story is good. Can't get into details. Read it yourself.
Translation is OK. Not as great as original Japanese text, but it's good.
Consider supporting the creators and buying the soundtrack + extra stories 
(i'm too broke for that unfortunately)

author: {'steamid': '76561198846700247', 'num_games_owned': 189, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 546, 'last_played': 1677477331}
review:
Narcissu is a minimalist kinetic novel, the art doesn't take more than 20% of the screen space with the rest of the screen being occupied by the colour of black, characters illustrations are far and in between, it doesn't have a text box and the texts that tell its story are placed in the blackâ€™s void. And while it does have voice acting, the developer suggested to play the game unvoiced for your first playthrough. Combined with the soundtrack that sings the songs of calm and sorrow, despite how it may look like the thought that the game feels cheap never comes to mind. The minimalist look gives the game a melancholic feeling and for the kind of story that Narcissu tells its readers, this aesthetic feels just right. 

The approach of minimalism doesnâ€™t stop with the visual or the sounds. While Narcissu used novel-style writing that is known for being verbose, the story intentionally leaves a lot of room for our interpretation, their emotions and thought process, their ideology, and nuance. Giving the readers the full picture is not something that the game is interested in. Thatâ€™s not to say that the story is cryptic, far from it. Narcissu still gives the reader just enough specifics to have an idea of what the story is all about, its messages, and the philosophy behind the ideas. But they donâ€™t give you all the puzzle pieces for the whole picture, the readers have to form their puzzle pieces and fit them in by themselves if getting the full picture is something that they desired. This approach makes the lack of a branching path feel irrelevant because each player might view the game in different ways in different playthroughs. An idea that they toned down for the second game as it gives a lot more info about the characters with an emphasis on details which gives a lot of context to the events of the first game, playing the 2nd game first is recommended.

The story revolves around the idea of living with death in mind, that you will never be like everyone else, living their life as they please, that even if they succeed or fail, at least they still have a future to look forward to. Itâ€™s a simple thing, but itâ€™s something that you donâ€™t have. The main characters of the games are patients on the 7th floor of a nameless Christian hospital, the hospice floor with windows that don't open more than 15 cm, waiting for their death. Each with their point of view of what their situation means for them. The fear of leaving the left behind with burdens, the desire to live life to the fullest, questioning your faith in God, is it better to just give up? The game delved into ideas that feel natural to come to mind if one is faced with such a situation. With the premise, it is easy to label it as a crying game, but the game doesn't want you to just cry, the game wants you to view it as a whole package with the hope that the messages might stick with you. The game tries its best for the reader to not be too sympathetic to the characters, they want you to be sympathetic to their ideas in a way that makes you go â€œAh, I think I get why.â€ In a way, this way of telling the stories might leave the characters feeling a little bit bland, but I found it to be beautiful.

Even though terminal disease and death is the prominent theme of the game, Narcissu is a story about living, the script has some typos and the minimalism might not be for everyone, but if the story that it told is the type of story that touches your heart, Narcissu is almost one of a kind. And with the free price tag that it comes with, Iâ€™d recommend you to check it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561199091572106', 'num_games_owned': 55, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1636945534}
review: Narcissu was one of the first visual novels I had ever experienced. I was in fifth grade at the time, but it's been a story that's literally always been in the back of my mind for the eight years since. I finally got the opportunity to play it myself and it's an even better experience. I'm someone who adores games with rich stories, and this one doesn't disappoint. It's a storyline that feels familiar and common at some points, but the execution is great. I love the soundtrack and the art a lot and the soundtrack is part of what's kept me invested in the story for eight+ years. This is one of my favorite games, and it's a game that I wish I could experience for the first time again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198377383336', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1634987459}
review:
Its an interesting read. I would recommend it if you would like to read something very heavy and very long. Do note that it actually is even less of a game than most Visual Novels; this "game" is more like a book as you don't get any choices, and the art is very minimal. You don't do anything apart from read, so it doesn't hurt to just turn on the auto-dialogue option and read it like a book. Although it might sound boring, drab, and un-interactive, the stories are written well-enough that it sucks you in and maintains your interest throughout the runtime, even though the characters fall kinda flat from time to time and there are some unresolved issues, [spoiler] such as how the hell did the guy steal his dad's car, take another hospice patient with him, and not cause a massive shitstorm? [/spoiler]

The problem I found with the "game" is that sometimes it is incredibly hard to follow and understand. It doesn't do a good job of telling which character is talking, and if what is written in the dialogue box is actual dialogue or a way for the game to describe a scene or the thought of a character. The VA does alleviate some of the problems, as they only talk in actual dialogues, but there are lines that looks to be actual dialogue but have no dubbing, and the dubbing is mostly relegated to Narcissu 2, and even then, sometimes its incredibly hard to tell who is actually talking because they sound way too similar, especially Yuka and Himeko.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051364586', 'num_games_owned': 150, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1638749980}
review:
Cute and short little utsuge kinetic novel. Not my cup of tea but the writing is pretty good.
Be warned that there is no interaction here except skiping dialogues and saving the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198209022040', 'num_games_owned': 218, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1634431877}
review: Narcissu is a beautifully crafted visual novel that brings us through the feelings evoked by life and inevitable passing. Despite it's minimal art and interaction, it tells a story that brings out your emotions and sticks with you long after you complete it. The feeling of longing it's melancholy environment shows us is unlike anything else, and brings you to understand the characters limiting situations, and the harsh reality life sometimes brings. A free, short novel that shouldn't be looked over.

author: {'steamid': '76561198218141715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 791, 'last_played': 1630705075}
review:
~Spoiler Free Review~

Despite being a VN/LN lover, I hadn't heard of Narcissus until one of my fave developers mentioned it, saying that it was an inspiration to him and was part of the motivation that caused him to start writing for VNs too.  I figured his taste was trustworthy, so I sought out Narcissus and gave it a go, and I'm so glad I did!

First off, I want to mention that the experience is best done by reading the novels in reverse release order; Narcissu 1st was the original VN, and then Narcissu 2nd, despite being released afterwards, is actually a prequel that sets up the events of the first game.  You get SO MUCH MORE emotional meaning if you read the prequel first - otherwise the weight of the events isn't anywhere near as hard hitting.  So I'd recommend reading 2nd before 1st.

As you may have seen from the description, the story centres around people who are in a hospice and already know that they're not going to survive their illnesses - their imminent deaths are not the be all and end all of their lives.  It's how they choose to approach those deaths, and how they live in the moments between, that tell this story.  Narcissus is a really good portrayal of that kind of scenario.  It has relatable moments, feels very real, and is a pretty accurate depiction of mindsets that people tend to have when they're in dire circumstances.  It also manages to portray this without being super depressing, or by relying on trying to throw massive emotional moments at you every five minutes - it's kinda just real.  The emotion comes through in the little things, and the characters are also written well enough that you feel for them as people, so those little things really count.

Since this is quite an old game, the visuals are a little lacking; it's not like a typical VN in that there are plush backgrounds with moving sprites overlaid, and fancy text boxes - it's very basic.  Despite this, the story was good enough that I found myself not minding this at all, and to be honest, it made the moments you actually did see characters on screen so much more compelling, because they were hardly present.  What keeps you in the moment is the great voicing, as well as the story itself.  The soundtrack, although not very large, is actually pretty effective and makes you get attached to the pieces in a positive way, cancelling out much of the potential monotony of a small roster of pieces.  I also like that there are multiple vocal tracks.

A little drawback is that, since there is no typical VN textbox/GUI, you can't see how to do certain things, like switching auto on, which is a big problem for some people.  If you want auto mode on, press A.  The game doesn't tell you this, which is a bit crappy - I read it in the reviews before playing, luckily, so I'll keep passing it on.  Oh god, I'm passing the rules on...  (play the VN to know why that's so noteworthy)

Overall, Narcissus is a relatively short experience (about 10-11 hours legit playtime for me), and though the graphics and soundtrack are somewhat limited, and it's a kinetic novel with no choices to be made, I really enjoyed it.  It really makes you think about life, and might even make you well up a little bit, but among all the sadness, it might just make you smile too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198967004630', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 974, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 745, 'last_played': 1710357815}
review:
I am rewriting my review, since a plot summary is not what a review is supposed to be. Enjoy a slightly better review.

This was one of my first visual novels, and what a great one to start my journey with. These stories will break your heart in the best ways imaginable. With a premise so depressing, like being a terminal patient in a hospice and escaping said hospice, or meeting someone weeks from their death, and forming the tightest of bonds before they die-- these two brazenly sad stories are some of the best stories I have read. Even now, after 10 VNs on my record (and especially then, when this was my second,) this game hold a very special place in my heart.

This game deals with death, depression, suicide, illness, and choosing between dying in a hospital, or surrounded by your family. It is heavy stuff. But that's why it's so good. They handled these topics near-flawlessly, with just words and simple pictures. Even through silence, you can feel emotion between every character. There is no romance to be found; just companions who want to help each other through their limited time. This game shows you that even in the darkest of times, joy can be found, catharsis is achievable, and the good vastly outweighs the bad, if you simply let it. 

The order I played these two stories greatly affected how they felt. I played the second story -- the one with the unnamed MC, first, meaning the money envelope was a mystery. Then I played the first one. At the end, I was crying for two reasons: because the envelope made sense now, [spoiler]and, of course, the death of Satsukis best friend.[/spoiler] I prefer the Second story, personally, but the first one had me good. I still get chocked up about the envelope, [spoiler] Satsukis and her friend's death, and MCs final "speech" about Satsuki.[/spoiler]

I do want to talk about one scene in particular, and how it was reprised at the end. Spoilers for the end, of course.
During MC and Satsukis road trip, they would stop by a beach, for Satsuki to stare off into it. One of these times, MC walks up to her, confused as to why she does this. She says something along the lines of "If I were to walk out into the ocean to die... would you stop me?" To which, he responds "I don't know... we'll just have to see what happens." Then, they both return to the car. I still think that would be the LAST thing you should say to someone who is fucking suicidal, but that's not my point here. At the end, MC and Satsuki do a bit of a photo shoot with a disposable camera, showing Satsuki in a swimsuit; the only recorded moment of her being happy. After which, she takes of her white wristband (meaning she's a resident of the hospice,) and begins toward the ocean. MC calls out to her to ask her one last thing: "Do you want me to stop you? Or, perhaps, you want me to give you a little push?" Satsuki smiles at him, replying "I'm not sure." and walks backwards, into the ocean, disappearing from sight. MC takes the wristband and developed photo, and drives off. I cannot remember exactly what his monologue at the end pertains, but all I know is that is was a strong ending to a Melancholy and Depressing story. The flawless callback to a small yet important scene makes the ending feel so much more impactful, and like a real climax to a sad story. And, the fact that who said what was switched; HE asked, and SHE didn't have an answer. Simply remarkable.

This game has a couple grammar errors, and I really wish the CGs existed, but I feel like they didn't want any colour in their story, unless it was important. That and the response MC made to the heartbreaking question needs to be fixed. Outside of that, there are no issues.

I don't cry. But this game made me cry. I'm welling up writing this, and it's been almost a year! This incredible game will leave you a changed person. I was going to give this a nine, but on second thought, I think it deserves better...

10/10, you won't be the same again...

review:
Okay, SO....

Install the game.
Then launch the game.
Then don't forget to SMASH that CTRL button like it's nobody's business!

author: {'steamid': '76561198162381766', 'num_games_owned': 629, 'num_reviews': 547, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1624112073}
review:
Questa visual novel Ã¨ composta da due giochi separati. Il primo Ã¨ narcissu, ed Ã¨ la storia di un ragazzo, il protagonista, che ha una brutta malattia che lo costringe a rimanere in ospedale. Qui incontra Setsumi, anch'essa con lo stesso destino del protagonista. Il protagonista decide di non aspettare in ospedale che arrivi la fine, perciÃ² decide di prendere l'auto del padre e insieme alla ragazza, vanno in giro per le localitÃ  giapponesi con l'obbiettivo secondario di trovare un campo di narcisi, i fiori preferiti dalla ragazza. I pregi di questa visual novel sono i disegni e le musiche, i difetti sono la lingua e il fatto che Ã¨ piÃ¹ un libro che una vera visual novel, non ci sono scelte, dovete solo e continuamente cliccare con il pulsante del mouse per mandare avanti la storia. Oltre che, se avete il joypad attaccato, questo va in conflitto con il puntatore del mouse. Nel secondo gioco che Ã¨ un prequel, impersonate la ragazza co-protagonista del primo titolo, un pÃ² di anni prima degli eventi narrati precedentemente. Lei, mentre sta facendo una visita di controllo, incontra Himeko, e tra le due nasce una grande amicizia che viene raccontata in questo capitolo. Ma non solo le sole, conosceremo anche l'amica e la sorella minore di Himeko. Anche qui, ci sono gli stessi difetti e pregi del primo titolo.

Per finire. E' un buon titolo gratuito con ben due visual novel. Ma, se non capite un minimo di inglese Ã¨ presso chÃ¨ inutile farlo partire, anche se Ã¨ gratuito. ^_^

P.s: Bellissima e malinconica la canzone finale del secondo epilogo del gioco. ^_^ Questo epilogo si sblocca una volta terminati entrambi i giochi. ^_^

hear me out
but im not very good with reading long series i just kinda wanted the achivements with the babes on it
good story got kinda bored around the end of narcissu 1 again i get bored easily i enjoyed the first part of it but i ended up skipping just most of it
PS: hold ctrl to skip all of the dialogue (to get the achivements) oh and also have a great day and hopefully you enjoy this game more then i did

author: {'steamid': '76561197969880352', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 2050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2050, 'last_played': 1585634073}
review:
This is a super traditional visual novel. I was hoping for something more, but there isn't much here beyond reading. And if that's all it is then the writing better be worth it. But neither the composition nor the story is all that great, IMO.

Your time is probably better spent reading a book that's actually enjoyable or playing a game that's actually fun. Narcissu is free, so I probably shouldn't be complaining. But free doesn't mean good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062247697', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 204, 'playtime_forever': 890, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 890, 'last_played': 1617557665}
review:
OMFG, 4h+ of pure NOTHINGNESS. The whole game could be summarized in a page and a half, yet the authors felt the need to loop conversations with slight modifications for OVER 4h!!!! I'm not talking about 4h of character development, with some plot twist, some revelation, some moral of the story at the end. It is not that. It is 4h of nothing happening for the sole purpose of nothing happening. 

- four hours, you said?
- yes...
- uhm...
- four hours...
- who'd have thought uh?
- hm
- do you like hours?
- not really
- what about minutes?
* the girl stares through the window *
- hm?
- I don't know if I like minutes
- I like minutes
- hm
- you wanna hear why I like minutes?
- not really?
* the boy sinks his head *
- I like minutes because they make up hours
- hm...
- and I like hours
- oh...
- but my favourite are days
- I see
- because days make weeks, months, years
* the girl gets sad *
- what is wrong?
- nothing
- I will take you to a clock museum, maybe that'll cheer you up
- okay
- do you wanna come?
- not really...

Linux port was flawless, achievements are redundant but okay. The only good thing about this "game" is me removing it from my "to play" list once and for all. I recommend it only to my worst enemies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009356603', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1619018963}
review:
I completely agree with the other popular negative review on here. This VN is a grind. It's so hard to get into because the girl is so depressed that she doesn't say much, doesn't really do much, and is constantly gloomy.  It becomes unbelievable that her companion is constantly shrimping over her.  Why? She wouldn't even look at him in their first few encounters and then he decides to [spoiler]run off [/spoiler]with this gloomy child of doom. Realistically, if someone doesn't even look at you when you talk to them, you would probably stop talking to them. But no, his mission becomes trying to please the deep gloomy void while trying to figure her out. She depressed bruh, it doesn't take 8 chapters to figure that out.  

Thumbs down, feels like dragging a dead body across a desert.

edit: 1st visual novel so I wanted to keep going. Part 2 is better than part 1; however, I felt it was way too long. It's pretty much double the length of 1.

review: It's been a really long time since I've completed this hidden gem. An unforgettable story to look back into after going through suffering in this cruel world. We probably don't think much of our lives or maybe even think that we are worthless... but please remember that many other people out there are living lives filled with suffering greater than ours and that is why we should never let our life go to waste - live on, fight with your everything to oppose this world's darkness, and become the change that you wish to see in this world: a beacon of hope for those who have fallen to despair.

review: More of a book and less of a game, Narcissu is an excellent work. However with its very dark tones and plot, i found it in the sort of category that I cant recommend to everyone, you should be wary if you get very emotional from empathy with characters and cant get to the happy part. But to everyone else this is an amazing book.

author: {'steamid': '76561199016429499', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 765, 'last_played': 1613750270}
review:
ItÂ´s a really, really wonderful visual novel, that deals with themes such as death, illness and friendship. I simply can not express in words how much I love this game. 
You donÂ´t have any decisions to make, so itÂ´s just reading text all the time, but both of the stories are really touching, well written and emotional (even though I gotta admit I slightly prefer the first one). There might be not that much artwork, but I personally like it that way and the pictures that you get to see are well drawn and aesthetically pleasing. And the soundtrack is just wonderful... Immediately fell in love with it.
The characters are charming and I felt really bad for them sometimes. 
This game will make you cry probably. But please give it a chance and play it.

review:
Finished it back in 2010 when i was still in the high school.
It is a very well written but depressing story. 
I can't describe it any better in words.
Simply spend 1-2 hours to read through  1 / 2, and you will know what i meant.

*Thanks to Key Fan Club in 2010 for the traditional Chinese version and also this on steam in English.
I have now a 2nd chance to read through this story again... still touching...

author: {'steamid': '76561199085857048', 'num_games_owned': 263, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1612317841}
review:
Soul-moving novel about illness, life and death. 
There's no comedy and no romance here (although there's character bonding).

You should know: the 2nd part is actually a prequel to the 1st. The author suggests reading them in reverse. 

This is more a text-based novel than a visual novel. Get it if you actually like to read. 
It uses minimalist atmospheric images, optional voice acting and leaves the rest to your imagination.

The music is very good and emotional.
It's mostly piano tracks, but some compositions have vocals and are fully orchestrated.

It touches spiritual/religious themes such as theological doubts and the loss of faith, so beware of this in case you're sensitive.

If you ask me 1 word to describe Narcissu I choose "tragic". 
YOU WILL CRY if you are able to immerse yourself in the story.

The word "narcissu" refers to a kind of flower that Setsumi -the charming girl you see in the cover- likes, as it reminds her of Himeko, a very important person in her life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142170883', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1611033905}
review:
(Narcissu covers sensitive topics which might not be suitable for everyone, so be advised)
Absolutely amazing visual novel. The stories are so well written and manage to address sensitive topics in such a fluid and emotional way. The characters feel so genuine and it's so easy to get attached to them. The music and artwork truly tie everything together. Take your time with the story and play with the music on, it makes the experience all the better.

author: {'steamid': '76561199007345993', 'num_games_owned': 5, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 351, 'last_played': 1608055035}
