author: {'steamid': '76561198331411585', 'num_games_owned': 246, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1614031069}
review:
[b] Side 1: [/b]

I knew how this would end.

[i] This is the story
of a girl whose heart was standing still
and a boy whose breath was being stolen away,
both of whom die. [/i]

I knew how this would end, so why? Why am I crying this hard? Maybe because it's not about the destination, but the journey itself. To surrender, to resign. Will you, knowing your end is near, fight? or will you accept it as it is? A beautiful tragedy, bittersweet until the end, masterful in its subtlety, "Narcissu" is a work worth your time. Realistic to the core, it will make you go through a concoction of emotions accompanied by the gorgeous background melodies and minimalist imagery. What are you waiting for? - our time on this earth is short, so enjoy it while you can.

[b] Side 2: [/b]

The 2nd side of the story ties the first one excellently. Every small detail in the first side makes now sense. The love for maps, daffodils, rules passed, curses - everything. [i] "If I were a saint. If my prayers weren't just for comfort. Then now, a miracle would happen...". [/i] Beautiful in its sadness, Narcissu 2 ties everything together perfectly, making for a complete narrative, bittersweet until the end. A serious theme presented in a flawless manner. I loved this story, and I wish for you to do too, because.. 

[i] in those dazzling days, those winter days, in times like these, it's okay to cry. [/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198150203031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1621341168}

author: {'steamid': '76561198355316398', 'num_games_owned': 171, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 539, 'last_played': 1575232856}
review:
Narcissu is one of a small number of games that made me cry. It is such as heartbreaking and beautiful game, and I'm so glad I got to play it.

Narcissu is split into two stories: Narcissu 1st and Narcissu 2nd. Narcissu 1st is about a man who is admitted to 7F, the seventh floor of the hospital, due to his terminal illness. There he meets Setsumi, a woman who is also terminally ill. The man finds out that 7F is the hospice, where the terminally ill come to be treated until they die. Additionally, he finds out that other than terminal illness, he and Setsumi have something else in common: both would rather die elsewhere other than in 7F or at home. Thus, they leave the hospital and set off on a journey, the final journey of their lives.

Narcissu 2nd takes place years before Narcissu 1st and follows a younger Setsumi, before her admission into 7F. Setsumi meets Himeko, a terminally ill patient, and the two strike up a friendship. From Himeko, Setsumi learns about cars, maps, and adventure, and in spite of her illness, Himeko's spirit seemingly never waned. Himeko's backstory is also revealed, in which she used to help other patients in 7F before her diagnosis of terminal illness. In similarity to Narcissu 1st, Himeko wants to take one final journey, and thus she and Setsumi set off to do so.

Both stories deal with the effects of terminal illness and loss. It is not easy to deal with the fact that someone close has a terminal illness. The entire livelihood of the one diagnosed with the illness is changed, and he/she will have to experience a slow but eventual death. The person's family and friends have to deal with knowing that loss will come in the near future, for there is nothing they can do to prevent death and raise the person's spirits to the fullest potential. The man, Setsumi, and Himeko realize these facts all too well. 7F should not be the place to die, where they're surrounded by medical staff and equipment in a setting that is all too familiar and painful. Home also should not be the place to die, where they're surrounded by family and friends who can only watch them fade away, who then must face the pains of loss right in front of them. There must be a better option.

When I read the game description, I was reminded of a famous line in William Shakespeare's [i]Romeo and Juliet[/i]: "A pair of star-crossed lovers take their life." Shakespeare literally tells his audience in the intro of his famous play that Romeo and Juliet will inevitably take their lives. The game description does the same: "This is the story of a girl whose heart was standing still and a boy whose breath was being stolen away, both of whom die." Now that sounds depressing, but despite the fact that death is inevitable, why does this game exist; why does [i]Romeo and Juliet[/i] exist? Then I remembered: a story is never just about the resolution, and an adventure is never just about the destination. They are about everything in between: the preparation, the journey, the setbacks, the miracles, the seemingly little things that culminate into something memorable. During their road trip, the man and Setsumi bought clothes, had their picture taken, and slept under a roof that was neither a hospital's or a home's, before finally reaching flowers, beaches, and open water. Before their last goodbyes, Setsumi and Himeko had food and drinks together, read maps, and climbed a mountain to reach out to open skies. Yes, death is inevitable, especially under the circumstances of terminal illness, but it is the time spent beforehand that truly matters.

In the end, the interactions and development of these characters, followed by their drive to truly live before they die and their subsequent journeys away from familiarity culminate into an absolutely sweet, heartbreaking, and above all, beautiful game. It is true that we will inevitably say our goodbyes sometime later, but it is important to live in the now. Time is precious, so make the most of it, and life will become that much sweeter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198437509458', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1609394255}
review:
I don't even know what to say. It's heartbreakingly sweet..

Edit: This vn is cruel, I hate it. I didn't know I'd end the year with a river of tears.

Edit (2): I have read hundreds of visual novels but this remains to my top favorite. It is beautiful in all ways possible, heart wrenching, and depressingly bittersweet. I always find myself going back to this from time to time. It genuinely makes you contemplate life and death, friendship and love--just human stuff. I will never ever get tired of reading this over and over and cry about it for hours. Thank you, Narcissu, for helping me feel what it's like to be truly human again.

author: {'steamid': '76561199057414677', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1606677705}
review: Absolutely classic, it's good to just read it for some extra knowledge. Like other comments said, it's a story about death and suicide, and there is very limited artwork with no choice in the game. Therefore your feeling of this story really depend on your own understanding of these topics. 1st is a delicate realism story and a good example of using sound track properly, even though the story does not make sense in multiple way. 2nd... I could not say it's boring or disappointing, but it's much longer than 1st and more anime-ish. So. I would suggest to spend 1 or 2 hours on 1st then have a rest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097351680', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1662499037}
review:
This a very sad story.
Although it is a short one this one was filled to the brim with character development as well as with memorable scenes.
It tackles a very hard topic and thankfully doesnt shy away to show how cruel or better to say unfair our world can be. 
For me it was a very genuine story which i have to admit made me cry more then i would like to admit, there were some moments where i had to stop reading because i basically couldnt stop crying. Music is amazing and cant listen to it without getting tears in my eyes. All in all I give it a 10/10 although it gave me a little bit (better to say a lot) of depression where I look around me and ask my self what the hell I am even  doing, I will never regret that I read this story. I can only recommend it to everyone to atleast read it once.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129176333', 'num_games_owned': 120, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1603856411}
review:
Feel free to comment with the similarly sad-ish VNs, if you know any
Possible Spoilers ahead (probably not, but continue on your own risk)
Somehow i never got myself to play the 2nd, so my comment is about the original(Insani Translations), hope the 2nd will delight me as much, if i ever make myself to read it. Works great when you want to think of how ordinarily sad life can be and to give yourself a push forward.

A great story, reasonably short, recommending to read it in one sitting, it will take about 3-5 hours depending on the rate of reading. Get some hot tea or drink of your choice and get comfortable.

I first read it about 10 years ago and i read it for about 5th time since then and it is as good as it ever was for me. Sure i wish there was more CGs, but it's laconic enough to get away with what it has:
Great Semi-Sad Story of two people who had their life shortened in all meanings, but still helped one another to get a taste of it. I only wish for a bit more of the protagonist's view and feelings on the situation as a whole. 
(Might read up on the 2nd soon, maybe it will get me what i didn't get in the original)
Great Music, i listen to it till this same day
Great, albeit a bit few, style
Great, laconic writing

author: {'steamid': '76561198368202358', 'num_games_owned': 75, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1664730053}
review:
Wooow... This was a roller coaster of emotions packed into a stunning visual novel. I cried. A lot. More than what I was expecting.

Short kinetic visual novel Narcissu has two stories that each deal with a terminal illness. All I can say is that you will experience strong gut-punches from emotions as you read this novel. Playing this and hoping to disappear into a fantasy world is not going to happen. The story of this visual novel is unadulterated, unfiltered, and stays true to the difficult, painful truth it explores.

If you want to read through this exquisitely written visual novel, there are a few things you should take into account. The narrative is divided into two stories. Although the second story takes place quite before the first story chronologically, reading the stories in either order won't significantly alter the reading experience. In addition, it is important to note that some of the content may bore some readers. This vn is rife with slow storytelling, a lack of character growth, and character CG. Narcissu might not be for you if you prefer watching the characters interact throughout the entire narrative and don't want to be stuck staring at still images of clouds, hospital rooms, and all the other background CG used.

Personal thoughts:
I really liked this visual novel, so I wasn't bothered by the slow pacing at all. I think of it as the reader taking on the role of the storyteller and gradually feeling the suffering that the characters we follow are experiencing, as well as the slow, monotonous life that they are forced to lead by the circumstances of their lives. I really liked how little character-specific computer-generated imagery was used. I felt lonely and depressed as a result of it. It fit in well with the way Narcissu is attempting to tell its story. That is, at least, how I see it.

As a final note, sadness with a large portion of crying and heartache is all you'll know when you finish this visual novelâ€¦

author: {'steamid': '76561198323539288', 'num_games_owned': 208, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 494, 'last_played': 1596463839}
review:
Narcissu is a VN about the lives of three people with a terminal illness. It has two parts and I'll talk about both of them.

Narcissu 1st follows Yuu Atou, a man who, due to his worsening condition, is sent to be taken care of on the 7th floor of the hospital. This is where he meets Setsumi Sakura, a girl who also has a terminal illness, and discovers that the 7th floor (referred to as "7F") is where patients with illnesses like theirs are sent to die with no hope of ever getting better. In an effort to find some meaning and closure in their lives, Yuu and Setsumi set off on a road trip, determined not to die on 7F.

Narcissu 2nd is the prequel to Narcissu 1st and follows a younger Setsumi, before she is admitted to 7F. She meets a young woman named Himeko Shinohara in a hospital, who has been admitted to the 7th floor. Himeko is a rambunctious young woman despite her illness, loves cars, maps, and adventure, while Setsumi is quiet, stoic, and reserved. Despite this, they become friends and share a commonality due to their illness.

Both parts deal with a common theme that most people can relate to, which is loss. It's handled very well, so well I cried near the end of both of them because the imagery, writing (besides some spelling errors), and soundtrack is so good that it hits just the right notes to replicate the feeling of loss. It's what a good story does â€• it develops the characters and makes them real enough for you, the reader, to care about them, and this is what Narcissu does very well.

It took me around 8 hours to finish Narcissu (which is quite long for a free VN), but it depends on how fast you read and whether you have voice mode on and you're just listening to the story rather than reading it. All in all, I recommend this VN, especially if you enjoy great characters and writing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198445544982', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 515, 'last_played': 1691710949}
review:
I recall once a line by Thomas Bernhard that everything is ridiculous when one thinks of death. I forgot exactly how he articulates the idea but it more or less expressed how much changes when one is confronted with the specter of illness and mortality. What truly matters and what can anyone outside understand about lives developed in the face of death, year after year?

I canâ€™t help but think the same whenever I read Narcissu. At its core, it is extremely minimalistic and short, having few of the accoutrements of most other VNs. A cast of two, few backgrounds and CGs, and an anemic playtime for anyone used to the marathon lengths of the likes of Fate/Stay Night or Muv Luv. But in many regards, this allows for a concise focus on the simple but poignant center of the VN, two terminally ill patients and what it is that matters, that anything matters alone on the precipice of death. 

The narrative itself is simple, two patients steal a car on their way to a place away from the hospital or home, a death away from the hospital or home. We are succinctly told that

[i]This is a story of so many things.[/i]
[i]But most of all ...[/i]
[i]This is the story[/i]
[i]of a girl whose heart was standing still[/i]
[i]and a boy whose breath was being stolen away,[/i]
[i]both of whom die.[/i]

There is only one inexorable conclusion. But knowing the events themselves says nothing about the VN, it is how it conveys the gravitas of death. Mortality and illness rob the two of any normal life, it makes even the smallest, trivial actions a bare struggle during their journey. But there is no melodramatic self-pity, no (excessive) soliloquys, no convenient surrender, it may not be boldly defying fate but it stands upright in its resignation. For a VN so occupied with death, it expresses the greatest appreciation for the smallest, most insignificant moments that make up life.
Perhaps not for everyone, but certainly worth the small time commitment for anyone with a remote interest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198270969269', 'num_games_owned': 34, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1597913689}
review:
Ever wanted to play a game that felt genuine? Ever wanted to see characters forming small relationships and having character development? Ever wanted to just laugh and smile upon seeing the characters monologue only to cry while reading the lines? Then this is the game for you. 
Upon first seeing this game I was pretty excited and anticipated a lot from this as upon looking at the synopsis I could see that it was going to be a beautiful story. And I can confidently say after finishing both the games, it was perfectly delivered and deserves to be read by more players. I don't really get why this game is free as it has rich characters, story and amazing music which helps with the feels but I can see that it was from long ago which is understandable. ( 2005 and 2007 ).
I recommend this to people who likes heartwarming and beautiful stories.
10/10 -Kimskerem, If I could erase my memories and reread it. I would in a heartbeat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045800334', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1624492809}
review:
Time doesn't show offline play. 

TLDR : First one is good, yet not fantastic, but the 2nd one makes the whole journey worthy. 

The first one falls in the "too easy" category in my opinion. This is not bad at all, especially for a free game : the music is good, the CGs minimalist but there's some reasons for it, but yet I found it too sentimentalist. For a bit more than one hour and a half, it was still a good starting point for a visual novel. 

The second one is far better. There's a real plot, there's some character development (we didn't have time to feel that much for the characters in Narcissu's 1). The whole plot comes in way harder, screaming its unfairness, and the whole religion subject was a really nice addition. It brought depths to Setsumi, and introduced Himeko which is very bright character. It's not only feeling thrown at your head, it's more of a real story :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198004204403', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 478, 'last_played': 1595431570}
review:
Quasi 9 ore di gioco per finire di leggere queste due storie molto toccanti e accedere all'epilogo "segreto" di Narcissu. Le due visual novel, velatamente interconnesse, affrontano il difficile tema delle malattie terminali, il senso della vita per pazienti molto giovani che si trovano a affrontare la morte e la visione delle persone che le circondano. Tradotte in un buon inglese, di lettura mediamente facile per chi conosce la lingua, annovera la curiosa presenza di una componente religiosa cristiana, che non mi sarei mai aspettato visto che le vicende si svolgono in Giappone. Bella ed evocativa la colonna sonora.

EDIT:
Nel 2016 Ã¨ stata messa in commercio una nuova versione a pagamento intitolata "Narcissu 10th Anniversary Anthology" che sconsiglio, perchÃ© ha gli stessi contenuti presenti in questa precedente edizione gratuita e le storie addizionali sono tutte vendute separatamente come DLC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072928605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 674, 'last_played': 1627262454}
review: Narcissu was probably the most depressing story I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing, I appreciated how it never held anything back with its painful realism. 1st hard to recommend due to its bland characters and lethargic pacing, but the story is forever burned into my memory regardless. 2nd then took everything I liked about 1st, amped up the characters, and expanded further on the themes. As such, I thought it was way more engaging and overall more enjoyable and memorable, while still being just as beautifully harrowing. Overall. a fantastic read worth the time and price of $0.

review:
Very good stories. But I won't lie, I'm still a happy ending fan. So if you are like me, you might not like it. 

Don't get me wrong, I loved both stories. But, as I said, I'm a happy ending fan, and sure would have loved if it was the case here.

All in all, it is still a very worth game to play. On top of that, it's free!

author: {'steamid': '76561198205833036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1587802468}
review:
Five easy achievements if you skip the reading. 
  If you plan on actually playing this, 3-5 hours depending on breaks, etc.
 
 [h1]   WARNING The following is a tad SPOILERIFIC! [/h1]
First death is sad, then there's another, and another, and another, and...  even the bloody dog ends up dead and he wasn't even really in the story, WTH?  

And lastly, I have an entirely different interpretation of the events and I'm calling serial killer. Think about it... who has been around for all the deaths AND ends up becoming the next Secret-Holder, eagerly anticipating the next patient?  Who admits the hospital is no longer accepting patients for the 7th Floor?   Because of... shenanigans.  Just saying.  :3

author: {'steamid': '76561198043595516', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1587796988}
review:
If you're looking to see if visual novels are right for you & don't mind a darker story, then Narcissu is an easy sell. With their strong stories, writing, & characterization being matched well by bittersweet OSTs, both Narcissu & Narcissu Side 2nd are more than worth the read, although my preference is definitely for the shorter, more focused story of Narcissu.

Narcissu: A short 2-2.5 hour reading time is all it takes for this bittersweet read to fulfill its purpose, but that's not to say the writing is devoid of poetic flair & exposition. I'd say that, even if you're perhaps unsure about the setting & maybe even the medium as a whole, Narcissu's short length & well told story are enough to justify seeing it through to its conclusion..

Narcissu Side 2nd: About twice the length of "Narcissu" thanks to a more fleshed out cast & (slightly) bigger scope. If you enjoyed Narcissu, then Side 2nd is a no brainer, offering further development & insight to the residents of Floor 7F. Again, a strong OST & improved art help bring the world to life, but it's the writing that really sets it apart from other free reads.

Overall, an absolutely solid recommendation - especially as you've nothing to lose besides perhaps a few hours of your time. As far as first VNs go, you could do a hell of a lot worse than Narcissu, but please don't think that it's all the medium has to offer if you do wind up not enjoying it, as it's one of the most varied & flexible storytelling mediums out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198382485371', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 153, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1585630943}
review:
I went back and forth a lot about whether I was going to recommend it.

First off, if you have depression or anxiety about death or being terminally ill, do not play this game. It's a very sad story, which between both novels, there was not a single chapter where the overtone of sadness didn't drown out any potential for humor or cheerfulness.

My only two complaints were that the visuals were definitely lacking relative to other visual novels that I've played, and the story was confusing at times, due to the stories being chronologically out of order, and the narrator switching perspectives between the stories.

With all that being said; the story, soundtrack and voice acting were fused together so well, that I was actually brought to tears. Make sure you read the second side FIRST, it comes before the first one chronologically, and reading it the other way around would make things pretty confusing.

Be warned, there are no choices in this one, and there are no happy endings.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012504050', 'num_games_owned': 512, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1579906181}
review:
Review of Narcissu 1st 

This is beatiful and sad but warming experience. I wouldnt even call this a game, its just a Visual Novel with no player input. Its like reading a book but its accompanied by beautiful music and tasteful pictures.

I dont think ive ever played anything like this. Ive finished 1st game in 95 minutes and i would urge you to play this game in one session, it truly is a unique experience. 

This "game" is a masterpiece. Music is beautiful, art is very fitting. Its just so great to find something like this. Most VNs offer huge storylines with complex twists - they usually require a lot of hours to fully explore them. This one managed to present excellent story, atmosphere and realism and feelings in just 95 minutes. It has many sad, melancholic moments. It has warm moments that will put a smile on your face (i know they put a smile on mine). 

Theres one more thing Narcissu did - i dont think there is any game that comes even close - It managed to show us, desribe to us true feelings of sick people - what comes through their head, what do they do, what are they thinking about, all of this just in 95 minutes of your time.

There are 2 lines that stuck with me:

"Purpose has been born, so was the fear of losing that purpose."
"We had a map, we had our meds, we had a car but we had no time. We had no future."


I know i will be remembering this game for a long time.
 If you have an hour and a half to spare, please try this piece of a game, it is truly amazing.

Review of Narcissu 2nd:

Didnt play yet, will play tomorrow.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125928371', 'num_games_owned': 232, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1564389981}
review:
So this is a book not a game. I can see how some people might think this book is cliche and not worth reading but I personally enjoyed this. This book is focused on how people deal with mortality. Because this book is short and free, I can't see a reason why you wouldn't read this book. Also if you want an easy 100% rate play through this game is perfect for that.
So stop reading this review and download this book.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198820460303', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1578466497}
review:
I played this game more than 10 years ago when I was about 11.

It was very good to have someone in the same age with me who wanted to commit suicide. Feels like I am not so weird eager to die when I was so young. Seteumi was the first one I met, so she meat a lot to me.

The suicidal narrative is really masterpiece. So touching that makes suicidal person feels better, even willing to live a bit longer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029075979', 'num_games_owned': 267, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1577030460}
review:
[h1]Tl;dr: It's as boring and depressing as the description implies.[/h1]

I'm finished with 1 and almost finished with 2 as I type this, and let me tell you... it's almost been painful to read through this. In a boring, nonchalant kind of way. Not because it's supposed to make you feel hopeless. Not a good thing.

I'm going to try my best to read the rest of it to see if it gets any more...tolerable(?) I dread every new section only because it feels like it's taking to long to be over. My mouth is so close to forming the words "just die already", and I don't enjoy that.

It's not a bad read, per say. But it isn't something I'd recommend, let alone be one of my favorite VNs. 
Not sure why this is as popular as it seems, tbh.

Not my cup of tea.

[i]Edited for formatting purposes.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561197969418821', 'num_games_owned': 3864, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1577511486}
review:
(Note: Currently reviewed after reading Narcissu 1st alone, and not Narcissu 2nd)

It's hard to put into words why I enjoyed this story.
Perhaps the relative short length made each chapter feel significant, or perhaps going into it blind and without any prior knowledge made the art style feel so different.

I definitely recommend it.  It has no choices or decisions, and while I was reading it, I felt that it was more akin to a Sound Novel, but I still appreciated it. 

After reading through Narcissu 1st and reaching the original title screen, you can see the notes from the author for the first game.  They really made the entire project feel fascinating and thought-provoking in terms of VN design.

review:
Sem palavras pra descrever... Uma histÃ³ria de poder emocional avassalador, mas que o desenvolve por meio da delicadeza, sutileza e humanidade.

Narcissu consegue, por meio de uma apresentaÃ§Ã£o extremamente minimalista, contar uma histÃ³ria emocionante sobre a vida e morte de jovens com uma doenÃ§a terminal, e como eles se relacionaram com todas essas emoÃ§Ãµes e sensaÃ§Ãµes inominÃ¡veis em uma viagem de carro de 900km, para alÃ©m de tudo provarem suas existÃªncias. Com as representaÃ§Ãµes grÃ¡ficas das personagens raramente aparecendo na pequena janelinha na tela, as paisagens tomam conta da narrativa visual e andam de mÃ£os dadas com a trilha sonora excepcional, que se molda a cada momento com maestria. 

Esta versÃ£o compila o primeiro jogo, de 2004, e sua "prequel" de 2007. Apesar de acreditar que o primeiro tÃ­tulo Ã© uma obra perfeita como Ã© e nÃ£o demandar nenhum tipo de expansÃ£o de seu universo, Narcissu Side 2nd Ã© uma adiÃ§Ã£o interessante Ã  histÃ³ria total, por explorar melhor os processos pelos quais Setsumi, a figura central da histÃ³ria original, passou anos antes, alÃ©m de oferecer um epÃ­logo cujo acesso se torna possÃ­vel apÃ³s a conclusÃ£o da leitura, que fecha os eventos desse pacote de uma forma muito gostosa.

Narcissu Ã© uma das pÃ©rolas dos jogos gratuitos da Steam, e recomendo demais a qualquer um com habilidade em lÃ­ngua inglesa que experiencie essa leitura que, apesar de curtinha, Ã© muito significativa. Como um iniciante em Visual Novels, essa Ã© uma Ã³tima porta de entrada, por ser uma leitura rÃ¡pida e linear, sem interaÃ§Ã£o do leitor com a continuidade dos eventos. Pra quem gosta de gameplay, esse Ã© um tÃ­tulo pra ficar longe... Mas como uma Visual Novel de verdade, Narcissu representa uma das melhores histÃ³rias do gÃªnero, com toda certeza.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066976171', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1400214387}
review: Really sad story & absolutely phenomenal soundtrack. Lamune79's and the main theme Narcissus gets stuck in my head from time to time. If you don't want to give the game a try, at least listen to the soundtrack on YouTube or somewhere. The game is free anyway so you might as well give it a try. I was really surprised a game of this quality was free.

author: {'steamid': '76561198189487495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1566786124}
review:
First off, you will only love Narcissu if you are a person who loves narratives, and can truly enjoy a masterfully crafted story. This will be true even more so if you enjoy books and visual novels in general; those only interested in gameplay and have no intention to immerse themselves in a story will not find Narcissu to be enjoyable, it takes patience and a willingness to open up to the narrative. Narcissu's 'fading' artwork, dialogue, and minimalist UI are artistic choices that also add to the mood and tone of the very tragic story which I believe fit the game almost too well. These decisions add to a style that makes you wish you knew more about the characters in the game, adding to the narrative and adding a bittersweet feeling to the larger conversation taking place in the game itself.

The story of Narcissu 1st and 2nd was some of the most eye opening work I've ever experienced, to understand and empathize with the people stuck in the metaphorical "waiting room". While we all bear the burden of a fleeting life and inevitable death, Narcissu manages to convey the struggle of knowing that without a doubt, on any given day, you can die. This connects to the sad and inevitable fate of a youth(s) having to confront this unbearable burden so early in life; the topic is beyond depressing, but it really does show the silver lining of life and makes you question many commonly brushed off questions like, "Is there a circumstance in which breaking the law is acceptable?". Understanding how meaningful that a last experience is to somebody is very difficult and illustrates just how beautiful life is, despite the existential crisis we all face and that even a little bit of joy can make our lives worth living.

Thank you for reading through this, I hope more people will receive the blessing of experiencing Narcissu; make sure to bring some tissues for the feels train!

author: {'steamid': '76561198254983136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1564531126}
review:
1. I've played a lot of sad games, but i am not one to cry easily. However, this game made me really cry and perceive life as precious. 
2. This is a visual novel. Like many others out there, this one can seem kinda slow making players drop out a little ways in. 
3.This one held my attention to the end. In school, all I could think about was this game. 
4. Despite all the sadness, there were plenty of parts that really made me happy.
5. Daffodils are amazing. I can't see one normally now. Literally my favorite flowers.
6. The soundtracks are great XD. I just listen to them as I study after i moved the songs over to my phone.
7. Take your time reading. I sincerely hope you like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168668883', 'num_games_owned': 191, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1222, 'last_played': 1567205173}
review:
I usually don't play alot of VNs but this was a VN that I had on my phone years ago and it just stuck so I had to buy it again on the pc.

The story is sad but beautiful. 

They both know their death is inevitable so they decide to go on a journey. 

If you know you are going to die, what will you do? How will you spend your time? Will you end it on your own terms?

review: Narcissu is one of those games that got picked out of a jumble of great visual novels and just stuck. Probably one of the best reads I have had in a long time. I love the game and its story so much and is one of the very few visual novels I have difficulty reading because of how heartfelt it is. Great story, great game, definitely has aged well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031654661', 'num_games_owned': 3513, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1558373769}
review:
Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a short and free kinetic visual novel that focuses on terminally ill people in a hospice. As you might expect from this concept, it's a pretty sad story but it's definitely worth experiencing at least once. The game has 2 different stories, 1st focuses on an unnamed male character as the protagonist and a quiet woman named Setsumi. 2nd is a prequel that features Setsumi as the protagonist, but it focuses more on a former christian named Himeko. I thought it was really cool how 2nd links back to 1st and explains a lot of small details about Setsumi.

The presentation of the game was pretty good, there aren't too many CGs but they do show up at key points in the story and I really dig the art style, you can get a feel for it on the store screenshots. The voice acting is pretty nice, some minor characters with only a few lines of dialogue aren't voiced which isn't really a huge issue, and the soundtrack is excellent. Lots of nice piano tracks and a few vocal songs. If the concept interests you, try it out! I really liked it and I can't wait to try out the 10th anniversary anthology project!

author: {'steamid': '76561198857646026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1614769227}
review:
This game honestly changed my life. Not everyone can enjoy this, it's slow, sad and a kinetic visual novel (No choices) but probably the most beautiful story you will ever read or rather experience. Gave me the inspiration to live my life to the fullest.
My favourite game along with Undertale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128383171', 'num_games_owned': 627, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 561, 'last_played': 1553168209}
review:
Beautiful and sad visual novel. 
Good story, soundtrack and voice acting.

Some reviews said there's no automode, but automode is available and started by pressing 'a'.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972297308', 'num_games_owned': 4482, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1553113063}
review:
If you knew that you only had a limited time left, how would you spend that time? And would you just wait for death to come, or would you try to end things on your own terms?

The 7th floor of a certain hospital is where people with no hope for a cure go to live out their remaining days, and it is here that the main characters of Narcissu meet, and together they think about the meaning of life and death.

While I prefered part 1 over part 2 both parts were good, and seeing as the game is free there is really no reason not to give Narcissu a try. Just be prepared to feel a bit sad after you've finished it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198215667311', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1546418890}
review:
I know, this is a popular storybook. And yeah, I know, I'm probably gonna get some quite heavy criticism if not outright getting my account banned for daring to say so, to give voice to my opinion. But ya know what? That's exactly 'why' I'm gonna give my perspective, as the fear of speaking out against what's popular is not a correct line of thinking. But with that said, I shall simply do my standard review format; Pros, cons, closing statement, and final verdict.

PROS: 

 + Beautiful music. I loved the piano melodies; they were so calm and serene. Then again, I am a bit of a piano nut, so..yeah. ^~^"

 + No hassle. This can just be downloaded and read, no problem, no configuration, no nothin'.

 + Voices are optional. There's voiced and unvoiced mode. I really, really like that. Granted, volume controls are fairly normal, but...yeah. It's nice to just have an unvoiced mode.

 + Most important part; it's free.

CONS: 

- Boring, uninteresting characters. It makes sense, but I literally cannot feel attached to either of them.

- Repitition. In some cases it's good for recapping, but in several moments the MC said the same exact thing twice in a row, back to back.

- Awkward writing. I'm gonna blame it on translation for this one, but yeah....it's not only hard to tell who is speaking when, but also a few instances of typos, albeit forgiveable, are still noticeable. 

- Dull plotline. We get it. They don't have much of a future. let's move on. Seriously. That seems like the whole premise of the entire story, is just driving in a more or less straight line across irrelevant places to do nobody-cares-what, not even the characters temselves really care about what's going on.

- So little is said, for how many words are there.

- No auto-mode. Sure, there's a skip mode, but not auto. 

- Choppy dialogue; literally everything happens and/or is said one singular sentance at a time. Which not only causes a few things to get rather disjointed at times, but also makes it so that you have to press the next button (in my case either enter key or space bar, though some people prefer clicking mouse 1) a LOT. Hence why an auto feature would be nice.

- Limited artwork. Granted, it's incredibly hard to make good-looking art for the full screen to enjoy, especially in an FTP book, buuuuuuuuut all the illustrations are made using just a single thin strip across the middle of the screen in mandatory windowed mode. I personally prefer windowed mode in visual novels, BUT the option between the two is nice.

Ultimately, it's nice that there are free Ebooks like this around, to give poorer readers and readers on a budget something to enjoy, but being free doesn't excuse it from it's mistakes. And it's flaws, while seemingly small, outnumber it's perks. Ultimately, this is a good story to read if you're bored out of your mind but can't afford a better VN, or if you've already read all the good ones and just wanna somehow read all the visual novels steam has to offer; maybe a collector or something, I dunno. But all in all, it wasn't a TERRIBLE story either. But if you thought you were bored before reading this visual novel, then your previous boredom would seem vibrant and lively compared to the boredom afterwards.

3 out of 10; below average score.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099219560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1545865277}
review:
This game is a masterpiece! I dont know why its free but this game was soo good and emotional and made me cry many times. Everything was fitting perfectly and really broke my heart. the japanese synchro was perfect, the feelings really reached to me and touched my heart. This game is a train of emotions and you dont know when it hits you bcs you get surprised sometimes too.

the story itself was just sad and put in soo much emotions i couldnt believe it myself. ok it laggs a little bit of pictures bcs most of the time the pictures repeat but they fill that gap with such an amazing and heartbreaking main story and side storys too that you didnt really care.i played the 1st and i thought it was ok but genually nothing special about it and then i played the 2nd and was flashed of how good it was (probably bcs in the 1st there isnt much voice too hear, so it gets boring after some time). like this game is free and it took me 8 hours to complete it and its from 2005 i think.

after completing this game i felt like i have watched an anime of the century, that is how good it was! after the main story there is an epilogue in the story and even in the main menu. also within the story you hear beautiful and emotional music that fits the scenery perfectly and you have an OP and an ED. this game gives you soo much content and did a great job with all the characters and really touched me. This game is a solid 100/10!! im out i have to get more tissues t_t

author: {'steamid': '76561198870494206', 'num_games_owned': 11, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1542836052}
review:
78/100

Narcissu is a kinetic novel split into two parts, each part detailing the story of a hospice patient from an outsiders perspective. The music is amazing, with mainly piano and guitar pieces, with multiple (I think four) insert songs. The actual visuals of the game are barebones due to the age of the game, as it squishes the 'view' into a small box, and writes text plainly underneath it. There are no names on the textboxes, and therefore it may be difficult to understand which characters are speaking at the beginning of each novel, unless you play it on voiced. The story itself is amazing, and whilst it didn't make me cry, it certainly made me think. Perhaps you'll also appreciate life the slightest bit more after playing this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067763182', 'num_games_owned': 1327, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1536517535}
review:
Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a set of kinetic novels that more than likely will touch your heart.

This is one of the most heartfelt, real and powerful novels I've read. These stories are about people that wait for their end from a terminal illness, very touching and it's impossible to not feel anything towards the story characters. Fun, sad, unexpected - there's a lot to it and a lot to experience through the short time of reading. It has an amazing soundtrack, too. Give it a read, especially if you want to experience something more emotional and real.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995458843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 465, 'last_played': 1537180491}
review: Una Visual Novel "semplice", senza nessuna pretesa. Disegni molto belli, musica veramente eccellente, che riesce a colpire i cuori di chi si sa ascoltare, trama veramente coinvolgente. Una storia drammatica, triste, straziante, Ã¨ ciÃ² che vuole raccontare e trasmettere l'autore di quest'opera, celando al suo interno anche dei forti valori sulla vita. Narcissu Ã¨ tutt'altro che un'opera leggera, dunque siate ben preparati emotivamente nel caso voleste iniziarla. SarÃ  veramente difficile trattenere le lacrime dinanzi a molte scene, parole e musiche utilizzate durante la narrativa. La durata di ogni storia non Ã¨ molto longeva, si attesta su qualche oretta all'incirca, ma Ã¨ piÃ¹ che sufficiente per coinvolgere emotivamente il giocatore dall'altra parte. Un punto forte dell'opera Ã¨ la presenza del doppiaggio in lingua originale, in giapponese. Il doppiaggio Ã¨ superbo, Ã¨ semplicemente perfetto, riuscendo cosÃ¬ a trasmettere empatia nei personaggi dell'opera, anche senza dover necessariamente ricorrere al dover riproporre le figure dei personaggi negli scenari nella maggior parte delle location, come spesso succede nelle Visual Novel in generale. Se necessaria, credo che la traduzione in italiano la si possa cercare tramite patch da qualche parte, almeno per la prima storia. Se vi piacciono le Visual Novel e volete emozionarvi, non esitate, entrambi gli episodi sono gratuiti!

author: {'steamid': '76561198282020349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 391, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1533591936}
review:
This is a VISUAL NOVEL GAME.
A Story Divided into 2 Long Chapters.
Meet SETSUMI.
Some of the Available Locations, a Hospital where you Spend a lot of Time, your Car Trips,
Beaches, Your Home, a Church, Different types of SKY...
Follow the GPS Route of your Car and it will take you Many Places.
Entertaining Story to Read whole at Least 1 Time or more.
The Title NARCISSU (Narciso) Refers to a Yellow Plant with White Petals
that Appears in this Story Many Times.
Download on your computer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198846029669', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1539933666}
review:
Narcissu is probably the most depressing visual novel I've read so far. In fact, it's the ONLY depressing visual novel I've played so far. I've played quite a few VNs, and I love sad stories, but this was beyond sad. It was truly depressing.

In the very beginning, I was quite skeptical, considering on how it differenciated from most visual novels, but as soon as I deeper in the game, I could see that none of the differences really mattered, and if anything just made it that more interesting. After completing both games, I can honestly say that my favorite part, and probably everyones, was the story its self. It was so deep and emotional on such a higher level than other VNs I've read. Also, most music in visual novels aren't very good, and can sometimes be annoying, but the music fit so perfectly, and really set the mood for each scene and part of the story, and only made the visual novel that much better!

9/10

Side Note: I do not recommend Narcissu to those of younger age and/or those who can't take heavy content, especcially emotional content, as the story focuses around death. But, if you think you are up to taking this heart-crusher, then grab a tissue box, some ice cream, and a pair of headphones, cause things are about depressing!

author: {'steamid': '76561198095293908', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 360, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1531357251}
review:
Though I do highly recommend this game, it does have a few problems. I'll start with I actually adore Narcissu 1st. The story was slow to begin with but built up and well executed in the long run. This is by no means an actual game but a well told story.  I believe that it uses the visual novel style well. It is simplistic but I find it quite elegant and portrays the heavy emotions of the story well. 
My problems come from the 2nd side/story. I found it exceedingly bland and boring, lacking the power and interest the original story had. The relationships between characters were minute and many but it did not carry the same strength as the single relationship shown in the first game. I honestly didn't read the whole thing and just skipped through it to get all the achievements.
That being said, this being a free game, read the 1st story at least. It is fabulous and moving. It is a near masterpiece. If you care I also enjoyed the epilogue which is unlocked after viewing the stories. It managed to bring me back to the tone and quality of the first novel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043642717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1531206295}
review:
Achievements: All possible, very easy.  

Narcissu-- without spoiling anything-- was a very powerful visual novel.  While the visual aspects are lacking (not many character graphics, many scenes play out with just a black background), the music and story are absolutely gorgeous.  I often had trouble deciphering who was speaking-- given there was a lack of character graphics or dialogue tags.  That, however, was my only real complaint.  There weren't many spelling or grammar errors.  It was well written.  Definitely worth a read, especially since it's free.

author: {'steamid': '76561198413987657', 'num_games_owned': 3035, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1531172568}
review:
The visual elements are somewhat minimal, more of a slim slideshow as the text glides across the screen, but the novel part - the narrative - really hits home. This game is sad, but the good kind of sad. It tugs on your heartstrings in a manner that makes you wanna call or hug someone you love to let them know you appreciate them. And more so than the text, it's the music that invokes that reaction in you.

The game is free, and with how amazing the score is it almost makes you wonder if the game is actually an advertisement for the OST DLC, haha. Absolutely amazing soundtrack and easily the best part of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198303993330', 'num_games_owned': 1425, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1530716109}
review:
Narcissu follows 3 different people, and their time in the 7th floor, where hospital patients with no hope of getting better live out the remainder of their days. It's such a sad and melancholy story, that makes you value your life and the lives of those around you so much more. It's packed with emotion and sadness, but has a very valuable story among all the feels it brings.

I really enjoyed this visual novel. There are no choices, just a sit back and listen story split into two parts. (I recommend B side, or the second story first, as it takes place [i]before[/i] A side or the first story.) It deals with the topic of death, regrets, religion and suicide so if these are sensitive topics for you, I would avoid this novel. Otherwise, this is a very good story from the perspective of people who should have no hope left, and what they do with their situations when the world has not been kind to them.

Narcissu is a very "real" game. Everything that takes place in the story is something that could very well happen in real life. It's a slice of life novel, for when your slice of life isn't what you always hoped it would be. It's a heartwarming and beautifully told story, just as long as you can hold your tears back for the endings.

Like most small project visual novels, the translation is a bit off. You can still make sense of the story, but some things may be a bit confusing to understand in an English-speaking audience. The soundtrack is beautifully done, as is the artwork. It was strange to me that only a small sliver of art was shown with the dialog, but it grows on you and isn't too big of an issue unless you highly prefer that the art takes up the entire screen.

I really enjoyed this novel, and if you did too you should look into their second version of this game, the 10th Anniversary Project. It's free, sad, and wonderfully done for what it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056285701', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 98, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1528193765}
review: Best novel ever

author: {'steamid': '76561198191335503', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1578855641}
review:
This visual novel has an interesting story. It tells the story of Setsumi and Himeko. The patients on the 7th floor.

The 1st series is the story of Setsumi and the protagonist, They travel west across Japan's many highways and prefectures, initially not knowing where to go, but later collectively decide on taking the narcissus fields of southern Awaji Island as a somewhat arbitrary destination.

The 2nd series tell the story of Himeko. 
In my opinion, the story of Himeko's flashback while taking care of one of the patients in the hospice room (Himeko as a volunteer) and the part of the story where Himeko had to accept the bitter truth, She was hit by a deadly disease later on, is the best story in Narcissu, compared story of Setsumi.

author: {'steamid': '76561198817058967', 'num_games_owned': 496, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 635, 'last_played': 1544133058}
review: An absolutely fantastic couple of stories that will send you through a whirlwind of emotions. Were you to read them, I suggest reading 'side 2nd' first, then '1st', then the epilogue, as the chronology may make more sense there. Do take your time whilst reading it all and be sure to soak it all in. I couldn't recommend this enough; it is a gem and should not be missed out for anything.

author: {'steamid': '76561198219992421', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 576, 'last_played': 1528957513}
review:
While the beginning of Narcissu 1 was a bit slow and felt uneventful to me, the story definitely gets touching. Narcissu 2nd seems to explain a lot of things behind Setsumi's behavior and thoughts too, which was definitely really sad.

It's a short, great story that will make you cry and will make you think a bit more about how life is with impending death waiting for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198279051917', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1530738977}
review:
How I hope these stories do not have to be created,
for those who has a reason to fight against fate but there is no need to do so.
I thought I would cry so much, but it seems that a decade really is an antidote. 
Even most relative dates and things were forgotten.
But just every time you think they are gone, the past really passed.
There must be something out to remind you of them, and make you suffer as always.
GG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116795663', 'num_games_owned': 773, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1603729640}
review:
Do not come into Narcissu expecting engaging gameplay. This game is a visual-novel and a kinetic one at that, meaning that it does not contain any choices, just like actual books. 

Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a game collection consisting of two games. The main one (Narcissu 1st) tells the story about two terminally ill patients escaping from their hospital and setting of on a journey of their lifetime. It is short (took me about two hours to finish) has good atmospheric music and tells a pretty good and depressing story. However it must be noted that Narcissu has lots of corny and clichÃ©d lines.

The follow-up, "Narcissu 2nd" is actually a prequel to the first game, that helps you make better sense of the first Narcissu game. This game is a bit longer (about 4 hours long). The soundtrack is really good in this one as well and the story, while containing lots of corny dialogue, is overall pretty good and made me feel a bit depressed. That is one strong indicator that you have made a good game, since I am someone that rarely feels depressed after reading a fictional story.

Give this game a try, it is free and does not take too long to complete. 

This game gets a 7/10 for its story and atmospheric music, but is dragged down from a higher score by its corny and clichÃ©d lines.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171453851', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1527273020}
review: These are both rather short visual novels exploring the themes of illness and death from the perspective of hospice patients. They are both rather minimalistic in style, as the art and music are intentionally designed to accent the story instead of being a huge part of the focus. They're short and touching stories, and I definitely think it's worth taking the time to read them (especially at the low, low price of free). I played them in chronological order, but the author actually recommends reading 2 before 1. I have to say it would really change your experience, though either order is good.

review: the stories are short (about 1.5-3h). the art is incredibly repetitive and very minimal. the music is very good albeit not very varied. The dialogues are also quite repetitive and there is literally only one voice actor... Yet, this VN manages to tell a story a deep and emotional story that had my attention from beginning to end because of the deep emotions that the story made me feel in such a short amount of time from the display of struggles and lost dreams thea the charactuers have. For a free VN you definetly need to give it a try as it will have you in tears in no time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093031831', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1436732097}

author: {'steamid': '76561198238119112', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1526309465}
review: Be warned. This game will break your heart many times over. Some parts may be dragging, but it's seriously worth it to finish the entire novel, especially part 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006891778', 'num_games_owned': 502, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1526746746}
review:
I've played this visual novel a while ago. Just decided to write a review.

First off, I really appreciate this as a work of art. It doesn't have to say much, but it does speak volumes. The contrasts of life and living, versus death and dying are very apparent. The 1st and 2nd are in slightly different settings, but it all revolves around how sometimes even life, when young, may be tragically cut short. The dying have to come to terms with it, even beyond accepting that fact. What matters is how they deal with it, and how much it transformed what they thought had in store for them in the future.

This is a "series", I should call it, which is really a story that comes in 2 parts in different perspectives. One of the living, one of the dying. It's hard to compare it to other games and novels I've read, because they don't often come to such depths, at least seriously. I would say this is worth a read in case you ever come to face such a reality.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098441931', 'num_games_owned': 49, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 550, 'last_played': 1522860212}
review:
As a program, and perhaps even from the perspective of game design, Narcissu is merely good.  Some script errors, mildly annoying voice acting in a couple spots, but generally well put together for hobby work released for free.
With that out of the way, however, I must say that this is easily among if not the best story I've ever experienced; I can not praise it enough.  For me, it is an utterly perfect progression of conviction, desperation, resignation, melancholy, and closure.  Narcissu never lets up for a second.  There is so much hurt and yet so much hope contained in this visual novel.  This is definitely something I will pass down to any family I may have in the future.

To all of those who've worked to bring Narcissu to live over more than a decade now, thank you from the bottom of my heart.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033169969', 'num_games_owned': 2300, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 2721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2721, 'last_played': 1522507630}
review: Although I would not call Narcissu a game, it is one of the very few reasons one could have for installing Steam. I have encountered almost an endless sea of boring, half-baked, marked by greed games on this platform; among those, Narcissu is a gem.

review:
The story is ok, albeit incredibly slow, but it doesn't make much use of the medium.
ie it doesn't have any business being a game. It's just text and a small handful of sparse backgrounds. It would be better off as a novel, instead of a visual novel with no visuals.

author: {'steamid': '76561198177110345', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1520665194}
review: Just to start with, I have played many games over the years. Probably in the higher percentile of gamers. I have not played many visual novels as of yet. But playing Narcissu I am completely taken aback. It was utterly one of the most heart felt, emotional  stories I have ever read. I was very glad to go along for the ride. The story was top notch. It was a very melencholy story from the start but it tugged forever at my heartstrings. I feel I am forever changed, getting a small view into a persons  life that has litteraly no hope of a future. Somehow still finding a connection with another human being going through the same experience. The emotianal ride of two people that had found each other in the later years of there short lives was nothing short of inspirational. There is much more I could contemplate on about the story, but I think you have to experience it yourself. To let let you know.... it is definately not a feel good story, because there is no true happy ending.  It does however make you think abou life and to make the most of it while we are here and that we absolutely need other human connection while we are here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198262452338', 'num_games_owned': 1861, 'num_reviews': 210, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1520712641}
review:
Two terminal cancer patients in their early 20's run away from a hospice because apparently Asian parents are so strict and cold-hearted that simply communicating how you want to spend your last months is not an option on the table. Better steal dad's car while he's visiting the doctor's office.

Please enjoy 3 hours of them buying rice balls and sitting in the car while it's raining. The same sentences will be repeated over and over and over while sad piano music is playing. When there's any dialog at all, the girl will just respond with "not really", "okay" and "..." in 90% cases.

[spoiler]In the end the girl commits suicide by walking into a winter sea apparently so that they never find her corpse or only extremely disfigured, so that she can get back at her mom for the above mentioned lack of communication. The man gets scared and goes back to hospice.[/spoiler]

Honestly, it's just another pointless spin on the dating sim formula. Barely fleshed out self-insert male protagonist, "wounded puppy" girl you can pity, most of the story is just pointless descriptions of shopping, eating, washing oneself, buying gas, etc, so that you can imagine yourself caring for your terminal cancer waifu.

And so you have it. There's really a fetish for everything.

P.S. This particular visual novel was one of the first handful to be translated into English back in the mid-2000's, which accounts for its relative popularity in the West, even though as far as VN's go this one is incredibly dry and devoid of almost any character.

author: {'steamid': '76561198413350620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1520076042}
review:
Won't be the first time you read this but it is good advice so I'm repeating it here before reviewing : Play Narcissu Side 2nd before Narcissu 1st because it will help make sense of some of the topics Setsumi talks of and you will see where they originated.

One thing I noticed is the difference in the tone & positivity Side 2nd has compared to the 1st, they both are on the subject of suicide/suicidal thoughts but it is more a journey of discovery for Setsumi in the 2nd as Setsumi witnesses the thoughts of an upbeat & lively Himeko who appears more accepting of her fate. 
Another detailed part of Narcissu Side 2nd is how it includes the Hospice & it's Catholic support which added a depth not seen in Narcissu 1st, to me it 'painted' a more complete picture by adding this religious aspect that subtly pointed towards the 'sin' of suicide. I'm not sure if this was intentional or if it was included for the reader to understand the beliefs being a Catholic (Himeko has Catholic upbringing) brings towards a serious topic like this. 
The translation of the 2 Narcissu VNs differs between Agilis and Haeleth, for me Agilis' translations were more direct yet emotional though Haeleth's versions added more depth to the story and seemed to have additional 'conversations' and came across as a more academic work wanting to include every detail just as a student would aim for in their thesis. 
In my view both translations are worth reading because it helps give a 'complete' visual experience of the novel and, after all, isn't that the purpose with VNs?

Narcissu 1st is a few chapters shorter than Side 2nd and delves straight into Yuu Atou (the Male protagonist) being diagnosed with lung cancer & upon entering 7th floor encounters Setsumi who now becomes a role similar to Himeko's in Side 2nd except Setsumi is much more reserved in personality. Yuu discovers Setsumi's desire to not finish up at home or at 7th floor so the two go off on an adventure that really captures the Reader as Yuu & Setsumi experience decisions that are both thrilling for them but also opens up a side to Setsumi that maybe she craved the whole time she was at 7th floor and that is - would someone care enough to want to stop her decision or would they respect it and honour it?

Between the 2 VNs the 'journeys' were similar yet from different perspectives in that Himeko was facing the same choices that Setsumi did in the 1st yet they were also shaped for Setsumi by Himeko. The music is exceptionally good and whether you do Voiced or Unvoiced the experiences would be lessened greatly without the music, that's not to say the art didn't play it's part because it did help add to the Visual side and complimented the story & the music. 

Overall, this is Free (that was a request made by the Author Tomo Kataoka) and, even though it covers a topic that is depressing because of the finality of it, the writing is a beautiful insight into cancer that is rarely explored from the mindset, beliefs and thoughts of the cancer victim especially as their time draws to an end. The question then becomes do they Live and seek out their wishes one final time or do they wait for the end without any freedom of choice?

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Liked what you see? You can find more reviews at [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32839633-Have-A-Word/]Have a Word[/url]
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

author: {'steamid': '76561198067361915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 821, 'last_played': 1518962959}
review:
ReseÃ±a completa [url=http://soul-swallow.blogspot.com/2018/02/narcissu-1st-2nd.html]aquÃ­.[/url]

En conjunto, Narcissu 1st & 2nd es una obra fantÃ¡stica que no puedo dejar de recomendar. Estoy seguro de que hay muchÃ­simas novelas visuales ahÃ­ fuera que le dan mil vueltas, porque siempre habrÃ¡ quien te supere en esta vida, pero resulta ideal para introducirse en el gÃ©nero. Puede que no tenga interactividad o varias rutas diferentes, pero creo firmemente que se han de apreciar las cosas por lo que son, no por lo que nosotros, en nuestra infinita ignorancia y egocentrismo, querrÃ­amos que fuesen. Efectivamente, puede que no haga mucho, pero hace muy bien todo lo que tiene que hacer. Por eso, ya seas alguien que ha renegado de los videojuegos toda su vida, alguien que se ha pasado 65 de las Ãºltimas 72 horas jugando a League of Legends, alguien que reniega de la literatura en favor de los videojuegos o, simplemente, alguien que disfruta de una buena historia, Narcissu 1st & 2nd proporciona diversiÃ³n para rato y, dependiendo de tus gustos actuales, puede que te descubra un mundo que no conocÃ­as.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992174178', 'num_games_owned': 1507, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1518948893}
review:
Two connected Visual Novels about hospice patients waiting for their death.
Not my kind of setting it's surprisingly quite interesting read, good writing, soundtrack and art.

(ignore my play time i finished it on other version, this one was used on achievements, it takes minimum ~6h to finish both)

author: {'steamid': '76561198313667005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1518894222}
review:
It's emotional.  Story wise it's simplistic but a good one

Stories like these really make my heart hurt. I haven't watched/read something emotional in a long time. The last thing I remember watching that got me crying was Ghibli's: The Wind Rises. But I'm someone who will cry over Kiki's Delivery Service & that's not a sad film <.<

Overall if you need a good cry give Narcissu 1st & 2nd a look

author: {'steamid': '76561198025674597', 'num_games_owned': 2059, 'num_reviews': 607, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1518734773}
review:
I must say I haven't played many visual novels, but I liked this one a lot. The story, which is divided between Narcissu 1st and Narcissu 2nd, deals with terminally ill patients living in a hospital in Japan. I can't really say much else without spoiling it, but I can say that it's a very touching story, which deals with some serious themes.

Like I said, it's divided in two parts, with the second one serving as a prequel to the first one, although I'd still recommend playing them in order. You also have the option to play with voiced dialogue, which is all in Japanese, while the text is in English. There's a few typos here and there, but nothing that makes it hard to understand.

Well, I don't have more to say. If you like visual novels, I recommend this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039137828', 'num_games_owned': 585, 'num_reviews': 322, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1515942294}
review:
[h1] Narcissu 1st & 2nd von stage-nana[/h1]

Eine weitere Visual Novel ohne EntscheidungsmÃ¶glichkeiten. DafÃ¼r aber auch ohne Preis, denn Narcissu 1st & 2nd ist kostenlos und dafÃ¼r bekommt man ganz schÃ¶n was geboten.

[b][i]Story[/i][/b]

NÃ¤mlich eine Geschichte die unter die Haut geht. Um genau zu sein eigentlich 2 Geschichten, diese sind inhaltlich recht nah beieinander und sind ganz unverkennbar das Herz dieser VN. Man kann beide auch getrennt voneinander bzw. in umgekehrter Reihenfolge lesen, ohne VerstÃ¤ndnisprobleme.
Im GroÃŸen und Ganzen geht es um Krankheiten, denn die wichtigsten Figuren der Geschichten sind Insassen eines Hospizes. Allerdings natÃ¼rlich nicht um die Krankheiten selbst, sondern was sie mit den Personen machen. 
Wie reagiert ein Mensch, wenn er weiÃŸ, dass es mit ihm zu Ende geht? 
Wie reagiert sein Umfeld: Familie, Freunde, Pfleger? 
Was soll man mit der restlichen Zeit anstellen, die einem noch bleibt?
Diese und andere, ungern gestellten und schwer zu beantwortenden Fragen, bilden den Kern der Geschichte. Hinzu kommen natÃ¼rlich die Interaktionen der einzelnen Figuren miteinander. Diese bestehen aber, gerade im ersten der beiden Teile, mehr aus Handlungen, als aus GesprÃ¤chen.
Beide Geschichten sind recht melancholisch und schwer zu schlucken. Die frÃ¶hlichen Szenen, die in beiden Geschichten vorkommen, im zweiten Teil auch deutlich verstÃ¤rkt, lockern das ganze angenehm auf. 
Geschrieben sind beide Geschichten sehr emotional und bewegend, in kurzen kleinen Textboxen, was das lesen, trotz der schwermÃ¼tigen Thematik, sehr angenehm macht. Lediglich die vielen Wiederholungen in der ersten Geschichte stÃ¶ren ein wenig (den Satz, dass das silberne Auto die StraÃŸe entlang fÃ¤hrt habe ich gefÃ¼hlt 100 mal gelesen).
Die Personen sind alle sehr unterschiedlich und auch wenn man gar nicht so viel Ã¼ber sie erfÃ¤hrt, fÃ¼hlt man doch mit ihnen mit und kann sich auch ein StÃ¼ck weit in sie hinein versetzen. Zumindest ging es mir so.


[b][i]Grafik [/i][/b]

Optisch macht diese VN keinen sonderlich guten Eindruck. Es gibt zwar einige Hintergrundbilder, viele davon sind aber recht langweilig, wie der Krankenhausflur oder die Armatur des Autos. Die Charaktere bekommt man nur sehr selten zu Gesicht, insbesondere in der ersten Geschichte. Sehr schade, denn das Charakterdesign ist durchaus gelungen.

[b][i]Sound[/i][/b]

Narcissu ist sprachlich vollstÃ¤ndig vertont. Zwar nur auf Japanisch aber ich fand dies sehr stimmungsvoll und fÃ¼r das Spiel absolut passend. Auch ansonsten kann sich die Vertonung durchaus hÃ¶ren lassen, auch wenn viele Titel eher traurig oder melancholisch sind.

[b][i]Fazit[/i][/b]

Definitiv einen Daumen nach oben. Ich finde es wirklich beeindruckend mit wie viel FeingefÃ¼hl und emotionaler Tiefe die Autoren sich hier mit einem unglaublich schweren Thema auseinander gesetzt haben. Die Geschichten regen zum nachdenken an und beschÃ¤ftigen einen noch lange nachdem man fertig ist mit lesen. Wie gesagt, es ist kostenlos, also seht es ruhig einmal an, wenn ihr etwas fÃ¼r VNÂ´s Ã¼brig habt.

[b][i]PS â€“ ein paar Kleinigkeiten[/i][/b]

Das Spiel gibt es leider nicht auf Deutsch. Wenn ihr normales Schulenglisch beherrscht solltet ihr aber keine groÃŸen Probleme haben die Geschichte zu verstehen.
Wer an Achivements interessiert ist sollte das Spiel auch unbedingt betrachten, denn die Erfolge sind schnell und leicht gemacht.
Wen die Spielzeit/Lesezeit interessiert, ich habe etwa 10 Stunden benÃ¶tigt.
Wer die Entwickler unterstÃ¼tzen mÃ¶chte oder noch weitere Kurzgeschichten von diesem Studio lesen will sollte sich das [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/426690/Narcissu_10th_Anniversary_Anthology_Project/] [h1]Narcissu 10th Anniversary Anthology Project[/h1][/url] einmal ansehen


[quote]Wenn euch die Review gefallen/geholfen hat dann folgt doch unserem [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/8049466/] Reviewprogramm[/url] und wenn ihr mir etwas zu dieser Review mitteilen wollt dann schreibt gerne in die Kommentare.[/quote]

Zwykle siÄ™gamy po gry po to, Å¼eby oderwaÄ‡ siÄ™ na chwilÄ™ od rzeczywistoÅ›ci, zapomnieÄ‡ o problemach i doÅ›wiadczyÄ‡ czegoÅ› przyjemnego. Nie tym razem. author: {'steamid': '76561197999470590', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1516325293}
review: Unfortunately a worthy subject is not enough to make a good piece of work. The original Japanese may be wonderful to listen to but the translation is stilted and painful to read. The music and images are pleasant but don't actually add much. The interface is dreadfully clunky. You have to click twice to bring up the end of each sentence, which makes the whole experience maddening. Sorry, this is a big thumbs down.
