author: {'steamid': '76561198185747370', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1432671725}
review:
First, probably important for you to know, I read the [b]unvoiced 1st season[/b]. 

So lets start: It's a non-optional visual novel, in other words, just mashing your mouse button / return key and reading is all you'll find in this game, paired with some sounds and pictures, suiting the story, and a soundtrack, supporting the actual mood of the story. The soundtrack contains - at least, as I guess, after playing for almost 3 hours - probably only two songs, but I didn't recognized this as a problem, yet it worked out really well, since you got to know whether that scene was sad or just glumly just by recognizing the right song. The sound effects also were fine, even if I got somehow scared, hearing - the first sound of a human, not a car or the waves - a girl crying and sobbing. 
Coming next to the pictures, I'm somehow unimpressed. I got the impression, that there are too less pictures. Plus pictures barely showed humans, making it very unlively. Also more than a few pictures were used too often. The effect, the soundtrack, containing only a few songs, had, reaches here for the opposite. It formerly tells you "yes, in the car again, nothing new, nothing exciting at all" and you may come to think it's really boring, not worth going on with reading. That somehow got to be my case, but there are also a few other points according to that.
The text itself is written from a to the protagonist limited narrator, containing very much dialogs. 
[i] And here comes the reason why I wrote "unvoiced" in bold in the first line:[/i]
It's unbelievable hard to follow who is saying what. When it was almost over, you could tell from the way the characters speak, who just said that, but in the beginning, it's a real pain and it confuses and makes the story incredibly boring.
Honestly, I was close to quitting the game mid-way. 
Well, I continued till the end, always thinking "no matter how sad it is going to be, since I was so confused in the first part, I won't be affected that badly (meaning I won't show any emotion like setsumi)". But I have to say, I was at least a bit wrong. It didn't got me that hard, but it [i]was[/i] somehow sad.

[spoiler] There is another problem, I had with the story: WHY THE HELL IS THE PROTAGONIST A GUY??! Either I missed that part, in the first few sentences or it was supposed to be like that. But now, I have a different view on everything what happened. It confuses me even incredibly more. I somehow dislike the protagonist being a guy, I would prefer that story, I already imagined all the time, dealing with two girls. [/spoiler]

If you wanna give it a try, being interested in this visual novel, please, for your own sake, play the voiced version.
I started the second season just yet, this time voiced, and until now, nobody except the protagonist - [i]a girl[/i] - was dubbed. I have no idea, if that's the same case in the first season, I won't try. I also won't go on reading the second season, because I don't think it's worth anymore, confusion being the cause.

I hope I did help you, deciding whether you should give this novel a try, since it's for free.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113610511', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 237, 'last_played': 1420567759}
review: Narcissu in a nutshell: an [b] emotional rollercoaster [/b] of a visual novel that will surely leave an emotional mark for hours after finishing it. Like any other visual games, this one is predicated on reading long blocks of text, accompanied by [b] beautifully-composed [/b] musical score, and some drawing. Not really fond of the art style, but the story more than makes up for it. Would [b] NOT [/b] recommend to anyone suffering from depression, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148120781', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1527410531}
review: Narcissu 1st & 2nd are focused on the theme of death from the perspective of terminally ill patients. This may not be a comfortable subject for some people. However, as everyone blessed with life must have a death, I encourage you to give it your time and consideration. My play time appears low because I finished them offline and Steam didn't log the hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148058140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1424039305}
review:
I read a different version that wasn't on Steam. Thus low hours. 

It was very sad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015893040', 'num_games_owned': 559, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1432440194}
review: Read the first one, not eager for the second. Painful story of death and suicide, and how we allow immovable realities to dictate our lives, and how we might change them a little by doing ridiculous, risky things. It's not an ineffective novel, but it is a bleak one. I don't come away from this book feeling I know much more than I came into it with, nor will I remember the characters. Nevertheless, it was poignant throughout, and well written. I would say that the author is talented and smart, but this book itself is a well illustrated process of slowly dying while grasping at the last few straws of life, and that is what reading it feels like. I simply can't recommend the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129215290', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 547, 'last_played': 1432310688}
review:
The Visual novel for Narcissu is great and highly emotional one. It is engaging made me want to play straight without stopping and in the process I started to ride the feel train. The story plot is decent about people who are terminally ill and was on the verge of dying. I somewhat could feel the emotional connection between the characters and made me feel sad that the game was over. The Narcissu 2nd is basically answering some of the questions raised in the Narcissu 1st. I wished there is more of it. 

If you are not looking forward for emotional and dark story, then this is not the game for you :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197999205069', 'num_games_owned': 413, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 500, 'last_played': 1453710990}
review:
Normalerweise kann man von "free to play" Spielen nicht zu viel erwarten. Dieser Visual Novel stellt jedoch eine krasse Ausnahme dar.
Man trifft keine Entscheidungen, bekommt jedoch eine tiefsinnige und herzergreifende Story, die einen nicht mehr loslÃ¤sst.
Vorwegnehmen mÃ¶chte ich nichts, es kann ja jeder selber schauen, ob der Inhalt einem zusagt, kostet ja nichts.
Wenn es einem gefÃ¤llt, so wie mir, endet es sicher nicht selten darin, dass man den Soundtrack (hier als DLC erwerbbar) kaufen mÃ¶chte, um den Entwickler als Dank fÃ¼r diesen kostenlosen VN zu unterstÃ¼tzen. Gut anzuhÃ¶ren ist er zudem auch noch.
Win/win.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028609055', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 606, 'last_played': 1432470779}
review:
This game was my first touch in a world of visual novels and I was instantly carried away with the story.
Very tragic and sad story, which makes you think about those who are suffering on a hospital bed, filled with guilt about being treated well by their relatives and giving up their hope about future.
The story line keeps you in touch and guides the reader through thoughts and feelings of a young dying person.
This novel is a must-see.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137412986', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 872, 'last_played': 1483120522}
review:
One of the games where I felt guilty for not crying.

Narcissu is different then anything I ever played or read. It has a similar theme like my favourite VN - Katawa Shoujo, but what sets it aside is its handling of matters of death.

Narcissu is like Fault in our Stars for grown ups, and yet different in its approach. Thanks for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001046455', 'num_games_owned': 13195, 'num_reviews': 349, 'playtime_forever': 505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1431550138}
review:
This horrible, horrible visual novel made be cry! As its intention was evoking emotions, it did the job.

Let's get down to business (I will keep this spoiler-free). Narcissu visual novels (VN) are not strictly games: they have no interactive parts whatsoever. You can just click away and the story continues linearly with no choices. Even the achievements are just reading the novels to their ends.

Narcissu (both of them) is a story about people [i]living with[/i] a terminal disease. Note the emphasis. It's a highly emotional and tragic story, with death being a constant theme. Nevertheless, the characters lives are what's important.

Curiously, the type of the disease is left unrevealed in all cases, emphasising the life of the person instead of the sickness. At all times the story follows one of the protagonists from their perspective, revealing what goes through their head. (Most) Protagonists and some important characters have voice-overs for their dialogue. Scenes are covered by nice, melodical piano songs and occasional other instruments.

Apart from many other visual novels, the visuals are very simple: usually there's just a serene scene that depicts the place where the events take place e.g. a kitchen or a countryside. There are very few scenes with people. The style didn't appeal to me strongly. However, I think that at important (i.e. dramatic) times the scenes were well done.

A couple of things about 1st and 2nd novels separately. In my opinion Narcissu 1st begins slowly, with the protagonist being admitted to a hospital and angsting away there. In Chapter 1 it seems like nothing is happening and frankly I was bored while reading it. Fortunately, in half-way through Chapter 2 it finally begins happening, so be sure to endure until that time. Narcissu 2nd is better in this respect as it has a branching story line from the beginning with several characters.

While both VNs are originally Japanese, there are fortunately two English translations of Narcissu 1st. The Agilis translation (the one I read thoroughly) has rather lot of typos and in some small parts it is left unfinished. To me it felt rather clunky. Only afterwards I briefly checked the gp32 translation and it turns out gp32 is a more polished and "proper" translation to English than Agilis. Narcissu 2nd has only Agilis translation to English that was fortunately a lot better and more polished than the one in Narcissu 1st.

For me, Narcissu 1st was 3-hour read and 2nd a 5-hour one. While it's possible to skip through the story by pressing CTRL for achievements, I can recommend reading through the story: it's an emotional and even revealing experience to issues and thoughts of people suffering from difficult diseases. As such, it provokes one to think about life perhaps from a new perspective. To me, that makes it worthwhile a read.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056671990', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1454976302}
review:
NOTE:Review is personal. Don't be a dick please. 

This novel is disturbingly sad and metaphorically makes perfect sense to me which touches me, and so far has hit me very hard as I suffer from dissociation on a daily basis, 

and have spent most of my days inside my own 7th floor staring at my pc screen listening to music doing nothing thinking nothing, strugging with addictions and health problems and dying on the inside and out 'trapped' in my home because of anxietes and fears, from past and semi recent abuse. no hope because no jobs.  In my room where i'll probably die. Abandoned, begged friends to be there but noone cares anymore. Faded, forgotten. Accepted it and gave up. Sad life. I don't wanna die but. It's impossible to truly live.

Don't play if your not already/don't want, to feel sad/depressed because trust me your about to be crushed. 

:) I'm only on the second chapter but will update about how I feel about this. sorry for bad review skills

author: {'steamid': '76561198143972439', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 286, 'playtime_forever': 605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1431820825}
review:
This visual novel is definitely worth giving a try if you like to read a beautiful but sad story. Unlike most visual novels this one doesn't have the characters speak to you, and appear in the picture, it usually merely shows a picture of the current location the characters are at, but despite that it's more enough to let you visualize, probably because the story itself is good enough to pull you in. And also the music is really good. It fits the moods and settings perfectly.

I've played visual novels I had to actually pay for before that were disappointing both story wise and lenght wise. This one is free, and is at least around 4 hours worth of reading and the story is actually really good. Emotional, yes. But in a beautiful and inspiring way. I wouldn't have minded to have to actually have paid for this visual novel, it delivers a lot more than some you have to pay for do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011712232', 'num_games_owned': 802, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1405042647}
review:
"Le Tour de Japon"

10/10 would sob again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001850566', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1431556653}
review:
It has no choices. It has no puzzles. It has nothing but a deep and heart touching story line about the meaning of life (and death) and those precious moments in between. What would you do if you knew you were dying, confined to a hospice floor? This is the general premise of the story, though there is much more to it than that. Thought provoking, with tender and human moments, this novel brought tears to my eyes more than once and at the end it was a story i was glad to have heard (read). 

My one and only dis on this would be the graphics. Don't get me wrong, they were nice, but they were lacking a bit. I feel they could have put more into the "visual" aspect of this novel. For example: the empty cars and grey screens. I get that it left more to the imagination, but it came off as a tad lacking in effort in my personal opinion. Still, for a free offering, this novel is wonderful and would have been worth paying a little for. 

Great rainy day read. 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198032281215', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 731, 'last_played': 1431553028}
review:
Best visual novel I read in years. It doesn't rely on visuals and there is no erotism but lot's of emotions, relies on it's writing style and soundtracks. There is a heavy use of piano in the soundtracks which adds more emotion to the story. We can clearly see that the writer didn't want it to be a tear-jerker, it made me cry, made me smile and at some place it made me think about my own life and my regrets.
   I recommend the voiced reading with auto-play since Setsumi's voice acting is really great. Though I can't say the same for Himeko. Her voice acting, also written in the Narcissu 2nd side notes, is faulty in some places but if you can overlook it, it's pretty much great, too. I also advice you to read all the notes after finishing the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971094921', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 533, 'last_played': 1430779037}
review:
Narcissu 1st & 2nd war meine erste Visual Novela. Zuerst sei gesagt: Es handelt sich hierbei nicht wirklich um ein Game sondern eher um eine Art Buch/Manga welches mit Musik, tollen Bildern und einer Sprachausgabe erweitert wurde. Wer nun ein Spiel erwartet sollte weiter suchen. Wer SpaÃŸ am lesen hat und auch vor einem zugegeben harten Thema nicht zurÃ¼ck schreckt sollte sich dieses Bundle nicht entgehen lassen. Die Story ist wundervoll geschrieben und ich hÃ¤tte niemals gedacht das ich bei so etwas wirklich damit kÃ¤mpfen mÃ¼sste nicht in TrÃ¤nen auszubrechen. Neben der japanischen Synchro gibt es eine englische. In der Patchsektion ist mittlerweile auch eine deutsche Ãœbersetzung zu finden - ich empfehle aber weiterhin die englische da einiges mit der Ãœbersetzung ins deutsche "merkwÃ¼rdig" formuliert wird und ein wenig unpassend wirkt. Nichts desto trotz kann ich dieses "Meisterwerk" wirklich nur empfehlen. Es hat alles was eine gute Geschichte braucht und es macht nachdenklich. Auch fÃ¼r den Einstieg in das Genre ist es eine tolle Gelegenheit zumal diese Novel free 2 play ist. Auch der Soundtrack lohnt sich! Viel SpaÃŸ beim erleben und mitleiden!

Story:   10/10
Musik:  10/10
Bilder:    8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198050944237', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1434147518}
review:
I've only been playing, when I say playing, I mean watching, Narcissu for about 2 hours so far, but I thought I would give my initial feelings.
This story is BEAUTIFUL, INPACTING, & VERY WELL EXECUTED.
I'm sucked in, and can't stop watching. I might update this review when I finish both Narcissu 1 & 2, but for someone who's on the fence about checking it out, DO IT! NOW! 
If you like visual novels, this is one of the best I have ever seen. MUSIC - 9/10, VOICE ACTING - 8/10, VISUALS - 6/10.
I know, 6/10? The is a little lack of diversity in the drawings/paintings, but the story is where it's at.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079300572', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 355, 'last_played': 1431754193}
review:
The plot has potential, but the protagonist is very self absorbed and the dialogue all feels like filler. 
It's important to note that I did not really spend as much time as it claims I did in this game, I minimized it once and forgot about it for a very long time. 

There was little plot, little variation in art, and an absurd amount of bland dialogue. The game is very long for what little there is to it, and I do not think it is currently worth your time.

review:

Mais un point commun les rÃ©unient : Ils vont tous les deux mourir. Ne suportant ni l'hÃ´pital, ni leurs propres maisons, ils dÃ©cident de s'enfuirent et de trouver un endroit oÃ¹ la fille veut mourir.
Nos deux protagonistes vont parcourir plus de 900km Ã  travers le Japon, alternant des moments heureux, de paix et des moments de confusion, de larmes et de dÃ©tresse.
L'ost est vraiment puissante et colle bien aux diffÃ©rentes situations (OST dispo pour 7 euros) 
Bien que le jeu soit en anglais, il est trÃ¨s comprÃ©hensible si on a un niveau correct et est gratuit.Non, je ne devrais pas parlÃ© de jeu mais d'histoire textuelle (light novel sans choix), un petit roman pleins de sentiments qui vous fera rÃ©flÃ©chir et vous fera voir et comprendre ce que ceux qui sont comdamnÃ© Ã  mourir dans quelques semaines ressentent.
Si une traduction en francais voit le jour, je me ferai un plaisir de le refaire pour assimillÃ© toutes les suptilitÃ©s de cette aventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119495883', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1211, 'last_played': 1431425717}
review:
UPDATE after finishing both the 1st and 2nd

This is truly a masterpiece. Beautiful moments, decent build up, and nice plots. Give the first a spin and if you like it, I can assure you that you will like(or even LOVE), enjoy, cry, touched when you are reading the second one. 

Make yourself comfortable, get yourself a cup of tea, sit down and enjoy. The soundtracks are sufficient enough to build up the needed atmosphere. Totally recommended!

Anyway, my first VN and it was impressively touching right to the kokoro (aka heart). :')

author: {'steamid': '76561198194790595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 634, 'last_played': 1430770954}
review:
Narcissu war mein erstes VN und ich bin begeistert!
Ich habe Abends eigentlich nur nach einer kurzweiligen Unterhaltung im Steam shop gesucht, da ich schon recht mÃ¼de und ebenso gelangweilt war. Ich entdeckte Narcissu, welches durch seinen Preis besonders hervorstach und meine Neugierde weckte. Das Ende vom Lied war, dass ich bis spÃ¤t in die Nacht vorm PC hing, weil mich die Geschichte nichtmehr losgelassen hat. 
Narcissu erzÃ¤hlt eine sehr traurige, aber ebenso schÃ¶ne Geschichte, die mit fantastischer Musik untermalt wird. 
Im Nachhinein wÃ¤re mir das Ganze auch ein paar Euros wert gewesen. 
Klare Empfehlung!

author: {'steamid': '76561198072745330', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1437092453}
review:
POSSIBLE SPOILER WARNING! I tried to avoid them as much as possible.          The game is self is split in to two parts, the first and second side. I made the mistake of playing them in the oposite order so that might affect my general rating of it. If you come into it expecting gameplay you will get none, are no choices to be made of enviroments to explore. Its entirely on rails. However as someone who just got into Visual Novels this didn't really bug me. The real meat, or should I say only meat is in the story. 

The first part is what I consider to be the strongest part of the game. You are immediately thrown into a hospice with no other explination. The rest of part one is the adventure the two main protaganists go on. The game did a very good job of pushing the story along. Although I did find it hard to relate with Setsumi, girl that goes along. Other than that Part one gets a strong recomendation from me. Most of the issues I have with the game apear in the second half

The "2nd side" more of a preqel if anything helping explain some of what happened in the 1st half. The 2nd side started really good, but ended on a poor note. They introduce my favorite charactor in the game Himeko who is an energetic car enthusiast. She shares and unlikely friendship with Yuka a girly girl who wears frilly clothing. The interactions between the two of them were quite charming leading to ocasional comidic banter. However in the second half she gets replaced by Setsumi, who is far less interesting in almost every way. There could have been an oppertunity to include her again later on however that doesnt really happen. The biggest problem that I have with the 2nd side, is the pointless shoehorning of religion. The ending had far less of an impact on me than it should have because of the constant reminder of the Catholic Church and praying. The whole thing felt like it was being wote by a Catholic, but I checked the notes and the author doesn't consider them selves "among the faithful". In the end however the story was good. even with the ocassional church sceen.

Ultimately I would recomend the whole thing. If you are a Catholic you will probably enjoy it twice as much as I did. Just understand that it's a visual novel and there is  no gameplay. Hence the term visual novel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031041930', 'num_games_owned': 303, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1430676034}
review:
It's a free visual novel, it made me cry. Isn't that all that needs to be said?

It starts a little slow, but then its really good. Not much happens in Narcissu 1 until Setsumi and the protagonist leave the hospital, and then the 2nd one is fine after reading the 1st and its a lot longer with more character development and story.

review: I really like it! It made me cry because it was so moving. People who seemingly have nothing else to live for, to find the good in something so small as a flower, it brings tears to my eyes and happiness to my heart. I love the music!!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198037586730', 'num_games_owned': 793, 'num_reviews': 415, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1430594711}
review:
I'm not sure that calling this a visual novel is a great idea. A novel, sure, but as for the visuals they are merely wide-ratio images. After the first few images it gets to the point where they don't really add much. If they had published it as a website/blog, with the images as headers, then I feel the experience would have been better. and in that format you wouldn't need to worry about clicking through each sentence, or dealing with the sentence autoplayer.

As for the story itself, I think its OK. A bit too depressing for my tastes, but it does seem to capture the essence of what it would be like to live with such a condition. The finality of it is hard to handle, but if you want an emotional story, then go for it. Some of the translations are, as expected, occasionally a bit off, but overall it is very good.

As I've said, clicking through the program [calling it a game would be a bit much, considering it is a linear story] can be tedious, and the program itself is a bit odd. The chapters don't seem to run off each other, it takes you back to the main menu after each one finished. And the addition of achievements is clearly an unwarranted gimmick here.

To bring this together, I've not got any problem with the story. But the game that it is wrapped up in is probably better off not on steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068531722', 'num_games_owned': 344, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1430578279}
review:
[h1]This game was made in 2005. At that time games had been created not for just gaining money.[/h1]

Many people say that it is a visual novel. I donâ€™t think that is the one.

Youâ€™ll not find neither plenty of pictures (backgrounds), nor the sharp plot. Youâ€™ll not be able to manage the game. Everything youâ€™ll be able to do is read. And I can assure that you would not be indifferent at the end. 

Narcissu 1st & 2nd  â€” is a history about two peopleâ€™s life for 1 month. These people are doomed. Even we donâ€™t face people like them every day, they still exist. And there are much of them.

Youâ€™ll feel all the experience and all the thoughts of main hero and his â€œcompanionâ€.  To be honest, I canâ€™t exactly tell you who is the main hero of this game â€” boy, whoâ€™s telling us a story, or a girl, whom he is thinking about from almost actually the moment when game starts.

In fact, this game doesnâ€™t even need much of backgrounds and â€œfreedom of choiceâ€, like we have in â€œEverlasting Summerâ€. Extremely exciting plot does everything.

By the way, I should say something about backgrounds. Theyâ€™re not much in here â€” just 10-15 pictures. But music is matched very accurately. It is the thing that gives us whole atmosphere of the game.

This game has a huge psychological effect. As you can see, it is free. I have noticed that all the nice and soulful games are always being made for a long time by some talented people and finally are free. Theyâ€™re made not by huge companies.

Never give up. Take your problems easier. Remember: thereâ€™s always someone who feels much worse then you right now.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198113218013', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1490058883}
review:
What I write: 
11/10 for my  eyes which were standing dry after chapter 8. Though finished it a way ago without steam, I still wish to make some hours with steam to make my review persuasive.(LOL) Would recommend Setsumi to my girlfriend, student and project adviser. (though I have none of them)

What I want to write: 
Actually I played Narcissu's app a while ago, approximately 2 years from now on an android phone. It was a warm May afternoon, and I got  a 2 hours off after the swimming class and before after-class curriculum. I had only a mobile phone, no homework, no friends around, and nothing to do but waiting for the curriculum. So I found myself so bored that I have to seek something interesting - except playing games on my phone that  I had cracked for several times. I checked google play store, with the keyword that I've  forgotten, and my focus was caught by an app with a cover of white background and a smiling girl. Its  name was â€œæ°´ä»™â€ (shuixian, means narcissus in Chinese). I downloaded it, thinking it was some kind of Life simulation bishojo game, which was a perfect way of wasting time. That's how I found Narcissu, the Chinese translated version. 

However, it's Narcissu. The result of playing this "Life simulation bishojo game" was that I had totally forgotten what was around me for the next 2 hours, because all my focus was on this novel. No matter how loud guys were when the class was over, no matter how warm the sunshine was, what I  could only feel was a kind of regretting, for something that I could not express at that time. That's Narcissu. I did not cry, but my heart was somehow hollowed at the time I finished it. That is Narcissu.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969387232', 'num_games_owned': 920, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 100, 'last_played': 1430624553}
review:
I haven't finished 2nd yet, but Narcissu 1st made me cry at the end (in a good way)! A Kinetic Novel (think of it as a long cutscene; there are no choices) that is the playground for minimalism, I was endeared to the characters before I knew what hit me.

There really isn't anything I can add that others haven't already said. It was well worth it to me to spend time reading/listening, and I plan on finding more of the author's work. Generally, it takes a lot for an author to evoke strong emotions, but Tomo Kataoka / stage-nana did it with little effort!

author: {'steamid': '76561198162290747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1430005258}
review:
[h1]It is a good type of sadness, named empathy[/h1] 

   This is a review tuned towards those who feel like putting off playing Narcissu 1st & 2nd either because they believe itâ€™s " a boring book", "sounds upsetting", â€œdonâ€™t like manga/animeâ€ or just cheese through in fifteen minutes for the achievements with the hope they might give it a go one nice, quiet afternoon in. Three are misconceptions and the latterâ€¦ deplorable.

Note:  This has been completed as a review with abstract views, especially due to the game's grave theme. 
This is worth your time, especially as an F2P game (you're missing out)!

* Semi-spoiler alert. 
    Does not contain extensive storylines but will hint at certain basic aspects of the plot which could spoil gameplay a smidgen.

* [b]TL;DR[/b] â€“ [u]A straightforward and conclusive review can be found at the bottom[/u]

[h1]Death of the young affects everyone[/h1]
    Be ready as the very private and personal events of death will unfold before you. It will not drag you to hell or kill you from boredom if you take the time to read it properly. It does a superb job of taking out the gut-wrenching and leaving minimal scars. Whenever young people die in a similar context I am reminded of the anime series, [i]Anohana[/i] (ã‚ã®æ—¥è¦‹ãŸèŠ±ã®åå‰ã‚’åƒ•é”ã¯ã¾ã çŸ¥ã‚‰ãªã„ã€‚) which I strongly recommend whether you like anime or not as it talks about the issue of loss and death for young adults as is done through Narcissu. It's a theme which requires more love from modern literature and media emphasis. Sharing more consistency with Narcissu is John Green's novel, [i]The Fault in Our Stars[/i] (there is also a film) so that may give you an idea of the amount of heartache and satisfaction Narcissu may offer as a sad but worthwhile read.

[h1]Reminiscent of the best 90s Japanese romance mangas but thankfully reads minus the drama overdrive[/h1]
    Closer to the likes of previously noted, popular modern young adult novels, Narcissu is oddly empowering as many stories like it are even for mature adults. You are a young girl without much time to live but still plenty of life left in you. It is down-to-earth and focuses on realism despite its medical inconsistencies so no character is perfect and there is no right or wrong on the perception of life, death and [spoiler]suicide[/spoiler]. Even the religious slant in Narcissu 2 refreshingly had no bias or distortion. I recently played [i]The Cat Lady[/i], which is a beloved game on Steam also deeply based on death and [spoiler]suicide[/spoiler]. But it had several points where equality disintegrated in a beaker full of acid-ridden negativity (you'll see the logic behind this if you play the game). On the other spectrum, Narcissu, like its title, is honed to a emphatically personal experience in a much more positive way without losing force. 

[h1]The idea of freedom and choice within a world that lacks it[/h1]
    Loss and pain through the death of a loved one is excruciating as well as highly disorientating. Looking back on several personal experiences, it feels distinctly like falling through limbo. It is the most earth shattering and realistic inevitability that could ever happen to any living soul. So it is my belief that many people understandably dislike any variation of such a storyline which hints death and desolation with no escape or way to "win", especially due to the likely sense of powerlessness it makes the player/reader undergo. [u][b]But this is about your death.[/b][/u] One of the main protagonists, you, are a terminally ill character dealing with the side effects of knowing you are dying and your physical being broken down. For those inclined to avoid dealing with thoughts of death, this is a basic and comfortable visual novel to imagine the decisions you may fall upon in the face of death and urge you to grow up from being afraid of thinking onwards to that deep, impending dark hole you're walking towards.

[h1]The absence of interaction in-game, does not detract from the interactivity out of game [/h1]
    Every time I come across a documentary feature or visual novel, I weigh the chances I will find it boring. It's the expected outcome of short films, documentaries, software and visual novels currently available on Steam due only due to the superficially stark contrast they display from the average fully interactive game. Time and time again, I am proved wrong to have ever fretted as sitting in front of a computer screen and clicking through a story is just as culture-driven within its own universe as any game can be and offers the reader a multitude of emotions from which most will benefit from as entertainment. The graphics may be uninspired, the art cute but barely existent, and the translations could have been better (fantastic for F2P) yet you can tell itâ€™s brilliant writing. With any type of reading, nothing beats a smashing story. That very story and the telling of it is what Narcissu excels at. I ended up interacting more deeply with other people who have played this game more than I have through other veritable games. [b]Narcissu is lightly philosophical and a fantastic excuse for a soul-searching expedition.[/b]

[h1] TL;DR & Basic details[/h1]
    [b]TL;DR[/b] - Narcissu 1st & 2nd both bring light to saying goodbye to your life prematurely, on an extremely personal level in the form of a visual novel that lacks visuality/aesthetics and is more towards a breezy but splendid read.

    [b]Basic details[/b] - Depending on a person's reading proficiency, this will take you approximately 5-6 hours to read through 1, 2 and the epilogue once. There are two versions of translations available for the first instalment but only one for the second. I personally found the first translator smoother (especially as it has both 1 and 2, but I read the second translator's version as well) but try both for a few pages to find your own preference. There are also voiced (Japanese) and unvoiced versions. Narcissu 2 has much more voice acting than 1 which only has the bare minimum. Decide which heightens immersion for you. Just as it is with audio books, some will dislike the voice acting (well done and professional). Having studied Japanese for a while and understanding a portion of what is said made reading much swifter. Narcissu 1 is a favourite for many so if you'd just like to read one, that's what I'd recommend. I can only imagine how wonderful it would be to read the original Japanese text as the descriptive writing is first-rate.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
    Ultimately, our protagonists are fighting the fight just like the rest of us. Our instincts to live, and the restrictions we are faced with (death, illness, suffering and loss), ends in discovering choices within those boundaries and our insignificant existences with bound limbs, to instead jump towards the metaphysical freedom and something much more dazzling than any other sign of human existence.


[i]Edited for typing error.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198090680079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1431043794}
review:
The story is so sad but so incredibly beautiful. Since the very first moment it drags you into the story and itâ€™s impossible to stop playing it. I could never imagined that something as simple as a visual novel would have such impact in my life. No matter how sad you feel, you most keep playing it, that's why it's so special. I will totally recommend this game to anyone.

I'm the kind of person who knows how special something is since the very first moment, so I can be completely sure that when I finish this game I will love as much as the beginning.

review:
OK,this game is my first Visual  Novel.It's for free,everyone can try it.
Usually I don't Â´Â´feelÂ´Â´ anything in video games or movies or something like that.
But this made me almost cry.I expected an end like that,but it was still too sad.
The artworks are okay,The music fits good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114152157', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1447863736}
review:
A beautiful and moving self pased movie. This free game expertly touches on the topics of terminal illness, suicide, and how a person should act. I would recommend it to anyone who is or has/had a significant person with such an illness. Narcissu doesn't claim to have the answers, but it instead tries to help explain.

The 2nd side is longer than the 1st, but together they add up to roughly 5-6 hours if the voice option is picked.
The soundtrack is amazing.
The art is masterful.
I would recommend being at least 16 years before pushing through Narcissu. The topics are clearly mature (not adult, just very thought provoking).

author: {'steamid': '76561198093723166', 'num_games_owned': 281, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1439733330}
review:
Dont do the mistake that I did, that I played this in unvoiced version.

****   ALWAYS PLAY THIS GAME IN VOICED VERSION   ****

--------------------------
> >> Review:
--------------------------
I really liked the story and the translation done by agilis. The translations were proffesional and screams words that are used to their maximum potential. Agilis really used every word in the dictionary he can find to suit the scene. I like the way he used words like "scrap" rather than "retro". 

If you possess a broad vocubulary, I suggest using Agilis' translation, as his employs some but not all of the scenes, deep words not know to the everyday joe. If you dont mind the technicality of the words and want just easy to understand scenes, then you go for gp3^2.

But when in doubt, go for Agilis. 

I also like the music they put into account in the vn. Really powerful music pieces makes the vn's more motionally deppressing. 

One last thing, ALWAYS and ALWAYS play the voiced version. Just like above, dont make the mistake like what I did. I did N1 on unvoiced version. Didn't cry tho, just deppresed by the story. And I felt the urge to do N2 on voiced. And It was significantly better.

Even if you dont understand what they say, the voice acting also compliments the disheartening story through varying tones of their voices. Voice acting is really good. Just play the voiced version, it will save you time. You will know this when you finished the game. ;)


>>>>    TL;DR     <<<<
=================================================================

Overall, I really like the game. The game, when N1 and N2 are both played, are worth more than 4-8 hours. I cant believe that this VN is free. Some will cry, some will be moved. Somehow, I didn't cried, just gloomy and and emotinally moved by the story. Play this game when you have spare time. Its because this game shoudn't be rushed.

SCORE: 9.5/10

What are you waitng for? Go play this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198017200784', 'num_games_owned': 857, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1430582290}
review:
Simply beautiful and sad.

Narcissu is a tale of joy, loneliness, sadness, loss and acceptance. The plot is realistic. There are no super heroes, miracles or happy ending. Instead what is presented is a sad tale about people whose lives have been unkindly cut short and how they deal with it.

Gameplay is more reminiscent to reading a book or watching a movie. There are no choices to make in this game like other visual novels. Instead you simply click to move on to the next scene to read as well as listen to the story. You can choose to listen to a voice version or non-voiced version, which have slighlty altered translations.

The audio is simply heartbreaking. Music is does a marvelous job at setting a sad, tense and happy atmosphere. Thankfully, you can listen to some of the tracks in the "Extras" section. There is only japanese audio, with subtitles provided for other countries.

I highly recommend this game to people who want a good emotional story or keen to read.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987674194', 'num_games_owned': 156, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1430253207}
review:
Narcissu is about 2 main characters on their journey towards death. Unfortunately for me and fortunately for those I have served, I was a 'helper', like this game described it, for "3" years. And it brought back many, if not all, emotions I encountered from the patients there, especially desperation and hope.

The lovely piano and its soundtrack adds a lot of depth to the storyline. With that said, it's difficult to determine who is who when there is dialogue. Voice actresses sound the same to me and there is no name assigned to the text they are saying.

Regardless of the downfalls, expect a very realistic narrative and emotional response from each of the characters. This game will humble you very quickly and give you insight on the journey of death that we will all experience one day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087047139', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 569, 'last_played': 1512250485}
review:
*SPOILERS AHEAD*


Well, before i start off with this review i would like to first  give my cincerest apology for my previous review which i am editing right now. Only after finishing the first part did i burst in outrage of how the ending is completely unfair and doesnt suit the game at all in any way.But...after finishing what is left of this visual novel, i came to the realization of how blinded i was by my own sense of justice. Yes the game may seem a bit brutal at times but that just comes to show the reality of our lives.It just isnt fair sometimes, but  during those dark periods of our lives even a small spark of light in the darkness can make you even show a....smile. That is exactly what happenned here. With Setsumi experiencing extreme loneliness during most of her life, feeling betrayed by her former friends who just became strangers later on, there was that one person that was able to show her some good parts of life even knowing herself that her life is coming to an end. Himeko.....she was the one who was able to shed the light inside her soul and become a close friend of hers. Despite Hiemko experiencing some of her own mental breakdowns in the past and thus becoming a former Catholic, she still wanted to help Setsumi out because she knew that she was going to live longer than her only because she was 15 years old. Fast forward 5-6 years later after Himekos death, Setsumi was left with an envelope which contained a hefty amount of money and a lot of maps entrusted to her by Himeko herself who wished for Setsumi to travel and experience the world, to "live her life" before it was too late. Even after travelling around and experiencing some parts of Japan with the other protagonist who was unfortunately diagnosed with a simillar type of disease, there was still missing inside of her that the male protagonist just couldnt understand. And finally after arriving to their final destination where they wanted to see the narcissu bloom on the island,which Setsumi learned about from Himeko during the prequel, there finally came the moment when Setsumi just couldnt handle it anymore and started crying after being asked by the male protagonist why she doesnt want to go anywhere anymore with him. By explaining to him that she cant handle hopes getting crushed and wishes not getting granted, that she just decided to give up from the very beginning and tell herself that it is all usseles, he couldnt say anything and stood silent. The day after their conversation he asked Setsumi if she wanted to maybe go around the beach for a bit and had the idea to hand over the bikini she had with her. That was the moment when Setsumi realized that she always wanted to wear thatt bikini but never got the chance to do it. After putting it on, the protagonist wanted to take her picture but....with a smile on her face. There it was when she realized that maybe some wishes can come true and that was one of them...to smile. After posing for a couple of shots and fooling around the beach for a bit she couldnt believe that for the first time she was having...fun. That was it. Later after saying her goodbyes to the male protagonist and being entrusted with his drivers license, she started walking towards to sea to end it all. But before she did that he stopped her to ask her if she wants to be stopped or pushed faster to the water. There it was when she herself wasnt sure bu then she started shedding tears and let out a genuine smile directly aimed at him. That smile itself was the answer to his question. And that is how her life came to an end. That type of ending just shows that Setsumi was confident with her choice because he showed her that some wishes even during those dark times can actualy come true which means that Himeko's prayed has been answered. For Setsumi to smile. Setsumi realized that and knew that her work is done and that she could rest in peace now knowing that her wish did come true in the end. It just comes to show that this one of those endings which tells us that having faith always is a high priority. To know that there is always even a spark of light at the end of the tunnel. From Nello's , Himeko's and Chihiro's prayer being answered, Setsumi finally realized that after all of her suffering , right before the very end of her life, she finally smiled and felt happy for a moment. That was all it took for her to say right before she walked into the sea that it was worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044838472', 'num_games_owned': 398, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 587, 'last_played': 1430193594}
review:
This is actually not a game, strictly speaking, as it is what you define a "kinetic novel", meaning that there are some (also recycled in the 1st part) pictures which accompany the written story (voiced or non-voiced in japanese) and the music. You may or may not enjoy reading this, it is also mostly based on how much english you know, as it is per most of the visual novels. You'll have to do no choices and just sit and "enjoy" the story, which before you ask or think anything, yes, it gets you emotionally and yes, it could be painful.

Personally, I find some passages of the novel a bit too "drama", even resembling things like One Liter of Tears. Aside from writing clichÃ©s, I've actually enjoyed - so far, with 2 chapters left from the end of the 2nd part.
The 2nd part in particular, for me, is a bit too overkilled drama in some points, while trying to give a sight of some things of the 1st part.

In the end, it is not the best novel around, neither the most polished (a lot of overused pictures, sounds...) but an impressive one. It really is painful to come back to this game, although you'll probably want to know how the story ends.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094053088', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1430203853}
review:
Narcissu 1st is the story about disease, about two young people are dying because it's their fate, right from the start.
Every ordinary thing in our daily life seems to be boring and trivial. But for them, every little thing could make the rest of their days in this world meaningful, an evidence that they are alive even they know it's just temporary and meaningless after all. They've dreamed of a normal life so that they can live, can become anyone that they want. But it's just a dream, a dream which never come true and at the end, Setsumi cried...
You can believe or not, I know exactly how they feel because I used to be like them. Desperate, impotent, regret, hopeless. This is what you feel when your death comes closer and closer. Even the little details they put into the story, the driver license, swimming suit can make me shed a tear because I empathize with their feeling, their pains.
I was too shocked by the ending.[spoiler]But finally, Setsumi has beat her fate. Dying on 7F or at home...nope, none of them[/spoiler]. You know, no matter what happen, we always have a choice and this world isn't fair so we can only choose the way to live and die without regretting...we'll never know what happen tomorrow.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079796664', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1444912305}
review:
Let me start it off by saying this game is real. Absolutely, beautifully, disgustingly real. It gives you things straight. It gives you a life experience that makes you feel as if you went through it yourself.

And this is extremely sad.
An extremely sad, but accepted tale.

11/10 Would not play again.
It's perfect as it is now in my memory.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994473539', 'num_games_owned': 447, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 798, 'last_played': 1430319015}
review:
Narcissu ist eine Visual Novel von Stage-nana in deren Handlung sich alles um einen anonymen Protagonisten schwacher Gesundheit dreht, der kurz nach seinem zwanzigsten Geburtstag mit einer tÃ¶dlichen Krankheit in ein Krankenhaus in Mito, Ibaraki eingeliefert wird. Dort trifft er Setsumi, ein MÃ¤dchen, nur ein paar Jahre Ã¤lter als er, die ebenfalls tÃ¶dlich krank ist. Die Novel besteht aus mehreren Teilen, von denen die ersten Beiden hier in einem Spiel kombiniert sind. Im Zweiten werden die UmstÃ¤nde um Setzumi und ihre Vergangenheit genauer beleuchtet. Der dritte Teil ist bereits erschienen, aber noch nicht Ã¼bersetzt oder auf Steam erhÃ¤ltlich. Hin und wieder wechselt die ErzÃ¤hlerperspektive, um Teile aus der Vergangenheit anderer Charaktere zu erzÃ¤hlen. Die Visual Novel legt seinen Focus auf die GefÃ¼hle und Gedanken junger Menschen, die sich mit ihrem unumgÃ¤nglichen Ende frÃ¼her befassen mÃ¼ssen, als es jeder verdient hÃ¤tte.

Alle Teile sind jeweils kurz, mit einer Lesezeit von zwei bis zehn Stunden, haben einen linearen Handlungsstrang und nur ein Ende. Im Gegensatz zu vielen Visual Novels gibt es keine Charakter Sprites zu begutachten. Sie besteht ausschlieÃŸlich aus CGs. Der Zeichenstil von Charakteren ist recht kindlich, beziehungsweise moe, und der Stil der HintergrÃ¼nde erinnert an die Nutzung digitalisierter Fotos. Zu Beginn darf der Leser wÃ¤hlen, ob die Novel mit, oder ohne Stimmen gelesen wird. Beides macht einen guten Eindruck, auch wenn ich persÃ¶nlich gerne die Stimmen und AusdrÃ¼cke der japanischen Sprecher und Sprecherinnen hÃ¶re, die einiges zur AtmosphÃ¤re beitragen, wie der grandiose Soundtrack.

Die musikalische Untermahlung passt hervorragend zum Ambiente und der bedrÃ¼ckenden Story und ist in ihrer QualitÃ¤t hervorragend. Einziger Wehrmutstropfen ist die etwas ungÃ¼nstige Abmischung der Sounds. Es gilt ein wenig mit den Sound Settings herum zu spielen, bis man die geeignete Mischung aus MusiklautstÃ¤rke, GerÃ¤uschlautstÃ¤rke und LautstÃ¤rke der Sprecher erzielt hat. Mein Tip ist, Musik und Sounds etwas unter mittlere LautstÃ¤rke einzustellen und die Sprecher auf voller LautstÃ¤rke zu belassen, da sehr hÃ¤ufig leise gesprochen wird.

Im Allgemeinen ist die Technik der Visual Novel mit ihrer AuflÃ¶sung von Maximal 640x480 und fehlenden Charakter-Sprites, fehlenden Textboxen oder Animationen nicht gerade das Non Plus Ultra, jedoch tut dies dem Erlebnis keinen Abbruch, da der simple Stil hervorragend zur Novel und ihrer Thematik passt. AuÃŸerdem verfÃ¼gt der Anfang des zweiten Teils, nach dem Prolog, ein wundervoll gestaltetes Intro, dass Ã¼ber fehlende Animationen wÃ¤hrend der Novel durchaus hinweg trÃ¶stet. Wem also Grafik nicht all zu wichtig ist, kann sich auf eine kleine, gute und sehr bewegende Geschichte gefasst machen.

Geeignet ist die Novel fÃ¼r alle, die sich â€“ unabhÃ¤ngig des Alters â€“ mit Tod und Verzweiflung auseinandersetzen kÃ¶nnen. Der bedrÃ¼ckende Unterton ist jedoch nichts fÃ¼r jene, die mit Schwermut nicht gut umgehen kÃ¶nnen. FÃ¼r alle anderen jedoch ein Machwerk, dass definitiv einen Blick wert ist, zumal die ersten beiden Teile auf Steam kostenlos zu lesen sind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047658367', 'num_games_owned': 1741, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 100, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1441126831}
review:
This is a wonderful VN that makes great use of sound and subtle imagery to tell a very heartfelt story. It's very short, but it certainly lands itself as one of the good ones out there. 

Also, its free, so you shouldn't have an excuse to miss it - unless you avoid VN's that make you feel depressed afterwards. This game excels at that. ;_;

author: {'steamid': '76561198113737140', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1430094557}
review:
Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a game /visual novel of a girl who falls ill with an unkown condition and goes to the hospital as her condition progresses for the worse.  During this story i have cried many times due to some of the heart spliting occourences she and her friends go through.  i would recomend this visiual novel to anyone who is selfish or inconsidrate 1 (makes u a better person by having you try to imagine what the girls friends, family, and her are going through such as hospis care and becoming more impoverished)  or 2 whomever is looking for a great story but does not mind the plot.  Overall I would give this game/VN a overall 10/10.


Kudos to the creator of this fanominal VN

author: {'steamid': '76561198017915215', 'num_games_owned': 481, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1430091843}
review:
... on that blindingly bright day ...
... on that very day of winter ...

This is a story of disease and suffering; of medication and adverse effects; of thoracotomy scars and cellular poisons; of the living who cannot help but to die and of the dying who cannot help but to live; of a resting place other than "on 7F" or "at home".

This is a story of so many things.

But most of all ...

this is a story all about how
My life got flipped-turned upside down
And I'd like to take a minute
Just sit right there
I'll tell you how I became the prince of a town called Bel Air

In west Philadelphia born and raised
On the playground was where I spent most of my days
Chillin' out maxin' relaxin' all cool
And all shootin some b-ball outside of the school
When a couple of guys who were up to no good
Started making trouble in my neighborhood
I got in one little fight and my mom got scared
She said 'You're movin' with your auntie and uncle in Bel Air'

I begged and pleaded with her day after day
But she packed my suit case and sent me on my way
She gave me a kiss and then she gave me my ticket.
I put my Walkman on and said, 'I might as well kick it'.

First class, yo this is bad
Drinking orange juice out of a champagne glass.
Is this what the people of Bel-Air living like?
Hmmmmm this might be alright.

But wait I hear they're prissy, bourgeois, all that
Is this the type of place that they just send this cool cat?
I don't think so
I'll see when I get there
I hope they're prepared for the prince of Bel-Air

Well, the plane landed and when I came out
There was a dude who looked like a cop standing there with my name out
I ain't trying to get arrested yet
I just got here
I sprang with the quickness like lightning, disappeared

I whistled for a cab and when it came near
The license plate said fresh and it had dice in the mirror
If anything I could say that this cab was rare
But I thought 'Nah, forget it' - 'Yo, holmes to Bel Air'

I pulled up to the house about 7 or 8
And I yelled to the cabbie 'Yo holmes smell ya later'
I looked at my kingdom

author: {'steamid': '76561198039278118', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1430070630}
review:
This is truly awful. Very little effort has gone into this and it shows. What particularly annoyed me was the terrible translation. Not so much spelling mistakes, but grammatical nightmares. Badly constructed and run-on sentences, confusing tenses, coupled with exceedingly poor punctuation, all combined to twist my mind into knots when I should have been enjoying a leisurely read. In a visual novel you would think language to be the most important factor, but often you are distracted enough in trying to make sense of the sentences. I really didn't think that would be where the user participated when I downloaded the game.

Because there is often a confused frame of reference you can be left in the dark over who is doing what exactly? "But they told me: that I was going to die." Who and why a colon? "It was the only thing (word) that left my mouth from beginning to end." "There was no way to escape it it seemed." "It seemed there was no way to escape it." Is a much less complicated construction. I did consider the developer used a young teenager for the role, and had done an expert job of replicating their moderate language skills. Soon however she reveals her age to be 20 years.

There is very little to do in the game, other than advance the text and it's lucky the developer provided a save feature. The story is tedious and extremely boring and the images add very little depth.

I'm not against visual novels because I thought Depression Quest was very well done and had some very interesting dialogues and user-participation. There's nothing like that here, and even though it's free it's a hard novel to get through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000873994', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1621225253}
review:
This isn't a game. It is a visual novel. Such a format is rather new to me and I was skeptical. It seemed to me that a lack of material in the form of words would make visual novels just incredibly short books, the lack of mechanics would make the genre incredibly boring games, and the comparitive lack of visual information would make the genre rather drab movies.

Well, it turns out I was very wrong. Narcissu 1st and 2nd are awesome just as they are. The background music does add significantly to the experience, and its pacing would not be nearly as effective to me in a film or book (and it certainly wouldn't fit a game).

It is a moving story about young people in palliative care and how they decide to live, and die. That doesn't really do it justice though. Another review described it better: "This is a story of disease and suffering; of medication and adverse effects; of thoracotomy scars and cellular poisons; of the living who cannot help but to die and of the dying who cannot help but to live; of a resting place other than "on 7F" or "at home"

There really is no reason not to give this story a try. You won't regret doing so.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016883291', 'num_games_owned': 946, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1410673233}
review: As of this moment, I have only played the first part so keep that in mind. However, I think this is a story you cannot miss out on, especially if you are a fan of visual novels. Narcissu is an old school kinetic novel that does not take long to play (~2 hours for part 1) but tells an emotional and poignant story about two people faced with adversity concerning life and death. I was truly moved by the time I completed it and consider it among the best visual novels I've ever played. There's no harm in trying as well since it's free so get going!

author: {'steamid': '76561198032918432', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1453260766}
review:
Released in 2005, Narcissu is a free visual novel created by Stage-nana. There are two parts to the VN, Narcissu and Narcissu Side 2nd. They are complementary to each other and I highly recommend reading both in order. If you don't read it in order... well it will probably be confusing.
It's very short taking about 3 hours or so, depending on how fast you read and whether you want to listen to all the voice acting.

Visuals:
Art is very minimalistic, and the backgrounds only cover about 1/3 of the screen
Kinda disappointing, but being a free game I can hardly complain.
While there aren't too many backgrounds and CG, the game is fairly short and takes place in only a few places.
So it completely makes sense. There are very very few character CGs and when do appear, it is just at the right time, and at the right moments to complement the story. Super minimialistic, yet effective in it's own way. 
Some say silence is an important part to music, and certainly applies here as well.

Sound:
Voice acting is good. Nothing outstanding but each voice fits the character. There aren't too many characters in the first place, but the voice actresses do a good job. 
On the Soundtrack, it is quite beautiful. All the tracks greatly add to the ambience; although a bit depressing to listen to alone. For such a short game, there are lots of different tracks. I've seen longer VN with only half the tracks that this game has. 12 songs for the first part, and 14 for the second for a grand total of 26. 
It even incudes a few vocal tracks! 
One complaint I have is the abrupt cuts in music during scene change, or at the end of a scene. I wish it had some sort of fade. The sudden stop to the music kinda kills the mood the game has. 

Story:
There are two parts to the story, Narcissus  and Narcissus Side 2nd
The first part is sort of like an introduction, but the 2nd is what completes the story as a whole.
While it is possible to only play the first part, you owe it to yourself to complete the second. Trust me, you'll feel a lot less depressed :(
The second part definitely wraps up the story and leaves with a glimmer of hope.
The plot is definetly not the main focus here. It is more about the life of each character and their emotions. Struggling with death and hopelessness. Again, going with minimalistic art, I'd say the story is very minimalistic as well. A lot of things are unsaid, giving a lot of freedom of interpretation for the readers. I quite liked this style, and allowed for some thought provoking dialogue. 

Beautifully written, and thought provoking, it makes you wonder what I would do in that situation. Could I have the power or courage to be hopeful in despair? 

If you enjoy Visual Novels, then go ahead and try it out!
It's free and there is nothing to lose~

author: {'steamid': '76561198031103229', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1429580910}
review:
Un visual novel sans choix, c'est forcÃ©ment nul ?
Eh bah non, on y va, on lance et on se laisse porter. 
Visuellement, c'est peu acceuillant, trop sobre, peu d'images, on a trop de noir sur l'Ã©cran.
VoilÃ , c'Ã©tait le principal dÃ©faut de ce visual novel.
Pour le reste, foncez. 
Une histoire Ã  la fois belle et triste sur des personnes qui ne peuvent Ã©chapper Ã  leur destin, mais s'offrent tout de mÃªme une escapade, portÃ©e par des musiques sublimes qui collent parfaitement Ã  ce qu'on lit.
La seconde moitiÃ© de l'histoire (second side) change de ton et colle plus Ã  la vie, mÃªme si l'on cÃ´toie toujours la fin de prÃ¨s. 

Un voyage inoubliable. Et gratuit.

Merde alors, j'ai dis gratuit ? Ouah, si c'est pas magnifiique Ã§a !

author: {'steamid': '76561198089942250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1648724859}
review: It is the best AVG game I've ever played! I could still remenber how many times I cried that night. Setsumi, hope you can get your happiness

author: {'steamid': '76561197997801929', 'num_games_owned': 2918, 'num_reviews': 407, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1429205308}
review:
I don't like how the story is presented.  To start, the translation options are cryptic, so the best option for your language is unknown when you start the game.  I chose Insani because it was the only one I thought was legible as far as its logo goes.  It turned out to be an English translation, but the voice was still in the original language, which meant the voice meant nothing to me.  This is an overly glorified e-book, so I hate the empty, wasted space and the very tiny window.  It seems unnecessary to confine the user/player/reader to a game window when they could be reading the book more comfortably from a full-screen e-reader app.  Oh, yeah, you can't full-screen this 'game'!  Hell, it would be better if I could skip to a specific portion of the story since there's no save option or any kind of actual gameplay (no choices).

Finally, the pictures are generic and have very little to do with the text.  You will see the same images more than once and not really understand why they're shown to you at all.  It's ridiculously lazy storytelling in my opinion.  I expected more relevant imagery from a visual novel.  In the past, I used to watch visual novels like this one which were amazing, but this one just isn't worth my time.  It's boring and implemented poorly.  I've seen better in free Flash animations back in the Newgrounds glory days! Yes, it's free, as well, but it's a big waste of time when you can get better experiences elsewhere without much effort.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075329410', 'num_games_owned': 433, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 610, 'last_played': 1426777758}
review:
Enredo

O cenÃ¡rio inicial Ã© um hospital catÃ³lico, no qual o sÃ©timo andar Ã© a Ãºnica ala do hospital onde os pacientes nÃ£o recebem nenhum tipo de tratamento, pois Ã© lÃ¡ onde ficam os casos sem soluÃ§Ã£o.

O protagonista Ã© mandado para lÃ¡ e encontra uma menina chamada Setsumi, ele percebe o quanto Ã© chato residir naquele local, mas ele estÃ¡ acostumado pois em sua vida toda ele passou de um hospital para outro. Ele se interessa por Setsumi, pois ela Ã© igual a ele. Um dia ela diz que nÃ£o quer morrer no 7F e nem em sua casa. Em um ato de impulsividade o protagonista rouba o carro do pai e comeÃ§a a viajar pelo JapÃ£o com ela, procurando um lugar para morrer.

Narcissu nÃ£o te passa uma grande mensagem que te ensina a seguir em frente, muito menos Ã© um romance sobre duas pessoas que nÃ£o tem nada a perder. Ã‰ uma simples histÃ³ria sobre pacientes terminais e como eles lidam com a morte.

Quando lidar com a realidade Ã© muito difÃ­cil as pessoas procuram um jeito de se manter fora dela, Setsumi faz isso ao nunca demonstrar suas emoÃ§Ãµes, enquanto para o protagonista o mundo real Ã© sÃ³ uma visÃ£o, como se ele estivesse longe observando tudo que acontece, ele nÃ£o se importa com nada, o que o fez ver a realidade por algum tempo foi a apatia de Setsumi.

Durante grande parte da histÃ³ria o protagonista nÃ£o tem rosto nem voz. Acredito que essa escolha foi feita para poder colocar o leitor dentro da histÃ³ria, fazendo vocÃª se sentir como se fosse o personagem. O autor de Narcissu disse que, um dia ele simplesmente quis escrever e saÃ­u Narcissu, se vocÃª vÃª alguma mensagem aqui, isso Ã© com vocÃª, pois ele nÃ£o tinha nenhuma intenÃ§Ã£o de mostrar algo a mais com o seu texto.

Ã‰ uma histÃ³ria curta e interessante, cerca de 5/6 horas de leitura. O grande atrativo dela Ã© sua narrativa, vocÃª se sente curioso para saber o que vai acontecer, como essas pessoas que vivem na sombra da morte irÃ£o desfalecer. Existem situaÃ§Ãµes atÃ© um pouco engraÃ§adas, ao fugir do hospital o protagonista se preocupa muito com a falta de dinheiro, vÃ¡rias vezes ele acaba pensando em roubar dinheiro para manter a viagem.

Acredito que o autor dessa histÃ³ria deveria vendÃª-la por pelo menos uns R$3,00. Ele gastou tempo com isso e existe uma certa qualidade.

Parte tÃ©cnica

Narcissu Ã© uma visual novel, um livro digital. O que hÃ¡ de se avaliar em quesitos tÃ©cnicos? Bem, nestes livros digitais existem dublagem, vÃ¡rias ilustraÃ§Ãµes sÃ£o empregadas para mostrar o cenÃ¡rio e uma trilha sonora toca a todos os momentos, as vezes os desenhos atÃ© se movem.

Em quase todos os quesitos Narcissu Ã© bem abaixo da mÃ©dia, as artes sÃ£o repetitivas, tendo em vista que Ã© um projeto gratuito de pouco orÃ§amento, faz sentido. A Ãºnica voz presente Ã© a de Setsumi, uma dublagem boa mas, existem poucas falas. Combinaram a personalidade reclusa de Setsumi com essa limitaÃ§Ã£o orÃ§amental, ela fala frases curtas, rÃ¡pidas e sucintas durante toda a histÃ³ria, em alguns momentos as gravaÃ§Ãµes sÃ£o repetidas, para ficar ainda mais fÃ¡cil para os desenvolvedores.

NÃ£o existem animaÃ§Ãµes. O Ãºnico quesito tÃ©cnico que vai alÃ©m do medÃ­ocre Ã© a trilha sonora, ela Ã© muito melancÃ³lica, combina perfeitamente com o clima e as situaÃ§Ãµes do enredo.

Narcissu 2nd.

Na verdade existe atÃ© um Narcissu 3rd, sÃ³ que esse nÃ£o tem relaÃ§Ã£o com o primeiro.

A versÃ£o do Steam vem com dois jogos na verdade, atÃ© agora sÃ³ falei do primeiro porque nÃ£o gostei muito do segundo.

Na parte tÃ©cnica ele Ã© muito superior ao primeiro. Existem muito mais ilustraÃ§Ãµes, existem mais de trÃªs vozes mostrando que o elenco cresceu, e as mÃºsicas continuam tÃ£o boas ou atÃ© melhores. Provavelmente o primeiro jogo teve um relativo sucesso para o segundo ser desta forma.

O que eu nÃ£o gostei foi do enrendo mesmo. Dessa vez ele nÃ£o Ã© rÃ¡pido nem minimalista igual ao primeiro jogo, ele tenta te mostrar uma histÃ³ria melhor desenvolvida sobre os acontecimentos que antecederam o primeiro Narcissu. Ele Ã© legal, fala mais sobre a experiÃªncia de se trabalhar em uma hospital, como as pessoas que trabalham com pacientes terminais se sentem, e uma outra visÃ£o de como lidar com a morte. PorÃ©m achei a histÃ³ria bem tediosa, ela Ã© beeeeeeem lenta e ao final dela, igual ao primeiro jogo, nÃ£o existe uma mensagem clara. Se vocÃª viu algo, bom pra vocÃª.

Ã‰ totalmente gratuito. Se vocÃª gosta de ler e quer algo diferente confira Narcissu 1st&2nd no Steam!

Postado originalmente em: http://1048596.blogspot.com.br/

author: {'steamid': '76561198057091331', 'num_games_owned': 180, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1447472622}
review:
Narcissu (1st & 2nd) provides an emotional story themed around terminal illness.
The music provides atmosphere of dreary, depressing and soft living. Very well done in fitting with the theme.

A food-for-thought experience while depressing, tells a memorable story to love and is definatly recommendable. Plus its a generously free experience, if your not familar with visual novels, its potentially great way to open up to the touching genre. Keep in mind this is a kenetic visual novel and does not provide choices to create a branching story line.
